question: Q.115) The Tendulkar Committee revised India's methodology for measuring poverty. As per the Tendulkar Committee, which criterion is considered to measure poverty?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Expert Group headed by Suresh Tendulkar (2009) recommended a major shift in the methodology for estimating poverty. It moved away from the earlier anchor of calorie intake and based the poverty line on a broader basket of goods and services, including expenditure on health and education. The poverty line was defined in terms of a certain level of Monthly Per Capita Consumption Expenditure (MPCE), which was considered necessary to meet these basic needs.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§∂ ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§≤‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§ú‡•ç‡§û ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§π (2009) ‡§®‡•á ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•á ‡§¨‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§ø‡§´‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•à‡§≤‡•ã‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§® ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§π‡§ü‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§∞‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§ü‡•ã‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§∞‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§â‡§™‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø (MPCE) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§á‡§® ‡§¨‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The committee specifically moved away from a purely calorie-based measure.
- India has traditionally used consumption expenditure rather than income to measure poverty, as consumption data is considered more reliable and stable, especially for the informal sector.
- Employment status indicates vulnerability to poverty but is not the direct measure of it.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•à‡§≤‡•ã‡§∞‡•Ä-‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§ö‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§à‡•§
- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§â‡§™‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§â‡§™‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó ‡§°‡•á‡§ü‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•å‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è‡•§
- ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§á‡§Ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§® ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The Tendulkar methodology resulted in a higher poverty line and a larger number of poor compared to the previous method, leading to a major debate on the extent of poverty in India.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§≤‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§™‡§ø‡§õ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§∞‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•Å‡§à, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§∏‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§π‡§∏ ‡§π‡•Å‡§à‡•§

classification.subject: Economics

question: Q.116) The foreign exchange crisis forced India to seek external support. Which institution provided India a loan during the 1991 crisis?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The core function of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) is to provide short-term financial assistance to member countries experiencing balance of payments difficulties. In 1991, India was facing a severe BoP crisis, with its foreign exchange reserves depleted. India approached the IMF, which provided a bailout loan to tide over the crisis. This loan came with the conditionality of implementing economic reforms.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑ (‡§Ü‡§à‡§è‡§Æ‡§è‡§´) ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§π‡•á ‡§∏‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ 1991 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ì‡§™‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§π‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≠‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§®‡•á ‡§Ü‡§à‡§è‡§Æ‡§è‡§´ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§∏‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§ü‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡•á‡§≤‡§Ü‡§â‡§ü ‡§ã‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§ã‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§• ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The **World Bank** provides long-term development loans, not short-term bailout funds for BoP crises.
- The **ADB** (Asian Development Bank) is a regional development bank.
- The **WTO** (World Trade Organization) deals with rules of trade and was not even formed until 1995.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- **‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï** ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ì‡§™‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï ‡§¨‡•á‡§≤‡§Ü‡§â‡§ü ‡§´‡§Ç‡§° ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ã‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- **‡§è‡§°‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä** (‡§è‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§à ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï) ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- **‡§°‡§¨‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ì** (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§†‡§®) ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•à ‡§î‡§∞ 1995 ‡§§‡§ï ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ó‡§†‡§® ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- As part of the crisis response, the Indian government airlifted 47 tons of gold to the Bank of England as collateral for a loan.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡•á ‡§ã‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç 47 ‡§ü‡§® ‡§∏‡•ã‡§®‡§æ ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§ë‡§´ ‡§á‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§≤‡•à‡§Ç‡§° ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§è‡§Ø‡§∞‡§≤‡§ø‡§´‡•ç‡§ü ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§

question: Q.117) Which statement best describes a key feature of a Public-Private Partnership (PPP)?
options: Government and private entities share responsibilities and risks efficiently.
Only public sector entities can participate in PPPs.
PPPs are only used for purely social (non-commercial) projects.
The public partner fully finances a project, while the private partner has no risk.
correct: Government and private entities share responsibilities and risks efficiently.

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Government and private entities share responsibilities and risks efficiently.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§è‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•ã‡§ñ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ù‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The defining feature of a Public-Private Partnership (PPP) is the collaboration between the public and private sectors. A key element of this collaboration is the optimal sharing of responsibilities, resources, and risks. The goal is to allocate each task or risk to the party best equipped to handle it. For example, the private sector might take on construction and operational risks, while the public sector might handle regulatory and political risks.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

question: Q.118) Biogas plants are most commonly used in which sector in rural India?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Biogas plants, often called 'gobar gas' plants in India, are primarily used in rural households. They use anaerobic digestion of cattle dung and other organic waste to produce methane gas. This gas is then piped directly into the kitchen to be used as a clean cooking fuel, replacing traditional fuels like firewood, cow dung cakes, and kerosene. It can also be used for lighting in gas lamps.

question: Q.119) How does the growth of tertiary activities reflect economic development in India?
options: It reflects improved services, urban growth and rising demand.
It shows a shift back to farm-based occupations.
It highlights a fall in manufacturing employment.
It indicates a slowdown in overall income generation.
correct: It reflects improved services, urban growth and rising demand.

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: It reflects improved services, urban growth and rising demand.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§¨‡•á‡§π‡§§‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç, ‡§∂‡§π‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- As an economy develops, there is a structural shift towards the tertiary (service) sector. This happens for several reasons: 
  1. **Rising Demand:** As incomes rise, people spend a larger proportion of their income on services like healthcare, education, tourism, and entertainment.
  2. **Urban Growth:** Urbanization creates demand for services like transportation, banking, and real estate.
  3. **Improved Services:** The development of the economy requires more sophisticated support services like finance, logistics, and IT for the primary and secondary sectors.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á-‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à, ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï (‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ) ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ì‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§¨‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§ï‡§à ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à:
  1. **‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó:** ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á-‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à, ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ó ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ, ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ü‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ú‡§® ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
  2. **‡§∂‡§π‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏:** ‡§∂‡§π‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡§®, ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§≤ ‡§è‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§ü ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§™‡•à‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
  3. **‡§¨‡•á‡§π‡§§‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§è‡§Ç:** ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§, ‡§∞‡§∏‡§¶ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§à‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§® ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Growth of tertiary activities signifies a shift *away* from farm-based occupations.
- While manufacturing employment growth might be slow, the growth of services is a separate, positive trend.
- It indicates an *increase*, not a slowdown, in overall income generation.

question: Q.120) What does globalisation mainly mean in economic terms?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Connecting to the world economy.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ú‡•Å‡§°‡§º‡§®‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- In an economic context, globalisation refers to the process of increasing integration and interdependence of a country's economy with the economies of the rest of the world. This connection is facilitated by the free flow of goods, services, capital, technology, and, to some extent, labor across national borders.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§• ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§§‡•á ‡§è‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ì‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç, ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§õ ‡§π‡§¶ ‡§§‡§ï ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§π ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ó‡§Æ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Stopping foreign investment, limiting trade, and closing borders are all policies of protectionism or isolationism, which are the direct opposite of globalisation.

- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡§®‡§æ, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ß‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The essence of economic globalisation is the creation of a global market where economic activities are not confined by national boundaries.

question: Q.379) Under the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act, 2003, which of the following was banned after 2006-07?

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: D) RBI financing of deficit
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- A key provision of the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management (FRBM) Act, 2003, was to prohibit the central government from borrowing directly from the RBI to finance its fiscal deficit. This practice, known as **deficit financing**, involves the RBI printing new currency to lend to the government, which can be highly inflationary. The FRBM Act banned the RBI's participation in the primary issuance of government securities from April 1, 2006.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The act did not ban external bonds, subsidies, or grants; it only aimed to bring them within a prudent fiscal framework.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The FRBM Act aimed to create a strong institutional mechanism to enforce fiscal discipline and improve fiscal management.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The FRBM Act targets have been postponed multiple times over the years due to economic challenges like the 2008 global financial crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic.

question: Q.121) Technological innovation was key to the success of the Green Revolution. The success of HYV seeds in India was contingent on which critical input?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The High Yielding Variety (HYV) seeds of the Green Revolution were highly responsive to specific inputs. Their high-yield potential could only be realized when they were used as part of a package. This package critically included an assured water supply (irrigation), chemical fertilizers (to provide the necessary nutrients), and pesticides (as the new varieties were more susceptible to pests). Without adequate chemical fertilizers, the HYV seeds would not have produced the dramatic increase in yields.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§â‡§™‡§ú ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ (HYV) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§•‡•á‡•§ ‡§â‡§®‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§â‡§™‡§ú ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§§‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡§¨ ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•à‡§ï‡•á‡§ú ‡§ï‡•á ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§™‡•à‡§ï‡•á‡§ú ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ú‡§≤ ‡§Ü‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø (‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§à), ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§â‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï (‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡§ï ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è), ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï (‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§®‡§à ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ü‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§•‡•Ä‡§Ç) ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§•‡•á‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§â‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡§æ, HYV ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•à‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:

- The Green Revolution was based on chemical-intensive farming, not organic compost.
- Forest cover is an environmental factor, not a direct input for the HYV package.

- ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•à‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®-‡§ó‡§π‡§® ‡§ñ‡•á‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§
- ‡§µ‡§® ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï ‡§π‡•à, HYV ‡§™‡•à‡§ï‡•á‡§ú ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§á‡§®‡§™‡•Å‡§ü ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç‡•§
- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡§≤ ‡§π‡§æ‡§• ‡§ï‡•á ‡§î‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§π‡§ü‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ (‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§ü‡§∞, ‡§•‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡§∞) ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.conclusion:

- The Green Revolution was essentially a technological package, and the synergy between HYV seeds, water, and fertilizers was the key to its success.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§§‡§ï‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡•à‡§ï‡•á‡§ú ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§î‡§∞ HYV ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú, ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§â‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ö ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•á‡§≤ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§´‡§≤‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§

question: Q.122) Who among the following joined the Planning Commission as its Vice-Chairman in March 1950?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Planning Commission was established in March 1950. While the Prime Minister (Jawaharlal Nehru) was the ex-officio Chairman, the day-to-day functioning of the commission was managed by a full-time Deputy Chairman (later designated as Vice-Chairman). The first person to hold this post was Gulzarilal Nanda, a prominent freedom fighter and labor leader.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

question: Q.123) What was the main characteristic of the Indian economy at the time of independence in 1947?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Predominantly agrarian with low productivity.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§• ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Indian economy inherited from the British in 1947 was stagnant and underdeveloped. Its most defining feature was its agrarian nature, with about 75% of the population dependent on agriculture. This sector was plagued by exploitative land tenure systems, lack of investment, and primitive technology, which resulted in extremely low productivity and widespread rural poverty.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 1947 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ú‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§¨‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ó‡§≠‡§ó 75% ‡§Ü‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ã‡§∑‡§ï ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä, ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§π‡•Å‡§à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Per capita income was extremely low.
- India was far from self-sufficient in food grains and often faced famines.
- The industrial sector was very small and underdeveloped.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§
- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞ ‡§π‡•ã‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§•‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
- ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ ‡§õ‡•ã‡§ü‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- Overcoming this legacy of a backward and low-productivity agricultural economy was the central challenge for India's economic planners after independence.

question: Q.124) Which of the following was NOT a component of globalisation in India's economic reforms?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Globalisation is the process of integrating a domestic economy with the world economy. It involves promoting international trade, not just local trade. Promoting 'local-only trade' would be a policy of protectionism or autarky, which is the exact opposite of globalisation.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ò‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡•Ç ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§• ‡§è‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ '‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ' ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§†‡•Ä‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Allowing foreign technology, liberalising imports (by reducing tariffs and quotas), and encouraging Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) are all core components of the policy of globalisation, as they increase the linkages between the Indian and global economies.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ, ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ (‡§ü‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§´ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡§æ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï‡•á), ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ (‡§è‡§´‡§°‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à) ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ, ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ò‡§ü‡§ï ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The globalisation component of the 1991 reforms marked a decisive break from India's earlier inward-looking, self-reliance-focused economic strategy.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ò‡§ü‡§ï ‡§®‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä, ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§æ-‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∞‡§£‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ö‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The reforms led to a dramatic increase in India's trade-to-GDP ratio, a key indicator of globalisation, from about 15% in 1990 to over 40% in recent years.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§®‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞-‡§∏‡•á-‡§ú‡•Ä‡§°‡•Ä‡§™‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ï ‡§π‡•à, 1990 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ó‡§≠‡§ó 15% ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç 40% ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§

question: Q.125) The Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management (FRBM) Act set limits on the fiscal deficit and public debt. What was the fiscal deficit target under the original FRBM Act by 2008-09?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The original FRBM Act, enacted in 2003, set forth a fiscal consolidation roadmap for the central government. The key target under this act was to reduce the fiscal deficit to no more than 3% of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) by the financial year ending March 31, 2008 (later extended to 2009). It also mandated the elimination of the revenue deficit.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

question: Q.126) Which of the following is an example of globalisation in India post-1991?
options: Entry of multinational companies like Amazon and Apple
correct: Entry of multinational companies like Amazon and Apple

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Entry of multinational companies like Amazon and Apple.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•á‡§ú‡§º‡•Ö‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ê‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§≤ ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Globalisation involves opening up the domestic economy to foreign investment and competition. A clear and visible example of this process in India after 1991 has been the entry and widespread presence of multinational corporations (MNCs) like Amazon, Apple, McDonald's, and Samsung. The reforms removed many of the barriers that previously prevented or restricted these companies from operating in India.

question: Q.127) What was one of the key effects of globalisation on the Indian economy after 1991?
options: Entry of foreign companies and capital
correct: Entry of foreign companies and capital

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Entry of foreign companies and capital.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- A central plank of the globalisation policy was to open up the Indian economy. This involved significantly liberalising the rules for Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) and Foreign Portfolio Investment (FPI). As a result, there was a massive inflow of foreign capital and a large number of foreign companies entered the Indian market across various sectors, from automobiles to retail.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§≤‡§®‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ (‡§è‡§´‡§°‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à) ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡§´‡•ã‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ (‡§è‡§´‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§π ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§®‡•á ‡§ë‡§ü‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¨‡§æ‡§á‡§≤ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ ‡§§‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Globalisation led to a massive *increase*, not a reduction, in foreign exchange reserves.
- It led to the entry of new private and foreign banks, strengthening the banking sector, not closing it.
- It led to a significant *increase*, not a decrease, in exports, especially of services.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§®‡§è ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§¨‡•Ç‡§§ ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü‡•§
- ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ *‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø* ‡§ï‡•Ä‡•§
explanation.conclusion:

- The inflow of foreign capital and technology through MNCs was a key driver of the high economic growth that India experienced in the post-reform era.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- MNCs ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§π ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï ‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§µ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§

question: Q.128) Employment generation became a focus in later Five-Year Plans. Which Five-Year Plan introduced the Integrated Rural Development Programme (IRDP)?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Integrated Rural Development Programme (IRDP) was a major self-employment program aimed at alleviating rural poverty. While it was initially launched on a pilot basis in 1978, it was launched as a nationwide program on October 2, 1980, which falls squarely within the Sixth Five-Year Plan period (1980-1985). The program aimed to provide income-generating assets to the rural poor through a mix of subsidies and bank credit.

question: Q.129) Gender disparities significantly affect human development outcomes. Which of the following indicators is NOT part of the Gender Inequality Index (GII)?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Gender Inequality Index (GII) measures gender-based disadvantage in three dimensions:
  1. **Reproductive Health:** Measured by maternal mortality ratio and adolescent birth rate.
  2. **Empowerment:** Measured by the share of parliamentary seats held by women and the proportion of women with at least some secondary education.
  3. **Economic Status:** Measured by the labour force participation rate for women and men.
Food consumption is not one of the indicators used in the GII.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

  2. **‡§∏‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£:** ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ü‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§õ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
  3. **‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø:** ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§¨‡§≤ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.130) In which year did India officially start economic liberalisation?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- 1991 is the landmark year in which India launched its comprehensive New Economic Policy (NEP). In response to a severe balance of payments crisis, the government of Prime Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao, with Dr. Manmohan Singh as Finance Minister, initiated a wide-ranging set of reforms. These reforms, often called the LPG (Liberalisation, Privatisation, Globalisation) reforms, marked the official start of India's journey towards a more open, market-oriented economy.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 1991 ‡§µ‡§π ‡§ê‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§π‡•à ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§®‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§®‡§à ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø (NEP) ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§¨ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ä.‡§µ‡•Ä. ‡§®‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡•á, ‡§°‡•â. ‡§Æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§® ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§∏‡•á‡§ü ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§® ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§è‡§≤‡§™‡•Ä‡§ú‡•Ä (‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£, ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£, ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£) ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§π‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§®‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§≤‡•Ä, ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞-‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ì‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ü‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ö‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§

- The year 1991 is considered a watershed moment that divides India's modern economic history into the pre-reform and post-reform eras.

question: Q.380) What is the primary aim of the Market Stabilisation Scheme (MSS)?
options: To control long-term inflows via forex trade
To curb inflation using CRR operations
To absorb excess liquidity through securities
To manage fiscal deficit with bond sales
correct: To absorb excess liquidity through securities

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: C) To absorb excess liquidity through securities
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The **Market Stabilisation Scheme (MSS)** is a monetary policy tool used by the RBI to absorb excess, durable liquidity from the banking system, typically arising from large capital inflows. Under MSS, the RBI issues government securities to suck out the excess money. The money raised is kept in a separate account and is not used by the government for its expenditure.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **B)** MSS is different from CRR. **D)** The funds raised are not available for the government's fiscal deficit, distinguishing it from regular borrowing.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- MSS is a sterilization tool used to neutralize the inflationary impact of large foreign exchange inflows without affecting the government's fiscal position.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The MSS was introduced in April 2004 to handle the massive surge in foreign capital inflows India was experiencing at the time.

question: Q.132) In 1947, the Indian economy was marked by deep poverty. Which sector dominated the Indian economy at the time of independence?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- This question reiterates a key theme. At the time of independence in 1947, India had a colonial economy characterized by underdevelopment. The agricultural sector was the dominant sector, contributing the largest share to national income (over 50%) and employing the vast majority of the population (around 75%). This dominance, coupled with low productivity, was the root cause of the deep poverty.

question: Q.133) What is the main aim of globalisation?
options: Integrate the Indian economy with the world
correct: Integrate the Indian economy with the world

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The main aim of globalisation is to foster greater interdependence and integration between different economies of the world. For a specific country like India, the aim is to integrate its domestic economy with the global economy. This involves removing barriers to the cross-border flow of goods, services, capital, and technology.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ö ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è, ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ò‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡•Ç ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§• ‡§è‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ì‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç, ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ-‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§π ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- While globalisation can indirectly spur local production to become more competitive, its main aim is integration, not just local production.
- Limiting foreign trade and reducing employment are outcomes associated with protectionism, the opposite of globalisation.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§® ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§®‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§® ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§è‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ú‡•Å‡§°‡§º‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The ultimate goal of integrating with the world economy is to leverage global markets, capital, and technology to accelerate domestic economic growth and improve living standards.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§• ‡§è‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§π‡•ã‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ò‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡•Ç ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç, ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠ ‡§â‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.134) Which of the following was NOT a part of the New Economic Policy reforms introduced in 1991?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The New Economic Policy of 1991 was famously based on the three pillars of Liberalisation, Privatisation, and Globalisation (LPG). Nationalisation, which is the process of taking private assets into public ownership, is the opposite of privatisation. The nationalisation of major commercial banks in India occurred much earlier, in 1969 and 1980, and was a feature of the pre-reform, state-controlled economic regime.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 1991 ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§®‡§à ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£, ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ (‡§è‡§≤‡§™‡•Ä‡§ú‡•Ä) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡•Ä‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á, 1969 ‡§î‡§∞ 1980 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞-‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø-‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Liberalisation (reducing government controls), Privatisation (transferring ownership to the private sector), and Globalisation (integrating with the world economy) were the core components of the 1991 reforms.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ (‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ), ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ (‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ), ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§• ‡§è‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£) 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ò‡§ü‡§ï ‡§•‡•á‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The 1991 reforms marked a fundamental ideological shift away from state ownership and control (like nationalisation) towards a more market-driven approach.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§®‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£ (‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£) ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞-‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§£ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ì‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡•à‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§¨‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ö‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§

question: Q.135) How did globalisation impact Indian industries?
options: Gave more competition and modern technology
correct: Gave more competition and modern technology

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Gave more competition and modern technology.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§§‡§ï‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï ‡§¶‡•Ä‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Globalisation had a dual impact on Indian industries. On one hand, it exposed them to stiff competition from foreign firms, which was a major challenge. On the other hand, it provided access to modern technology, foreign capital, and new management practices. This competition and access to technology forced many Indian industries to become more efficient, improve quality, and innovate in order to survive and grow.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•ã‡§π‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ ‡§™‡§°‡§º‡§æ‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ì‡§∞, ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§´‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§â‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§ö‡•Å‡§®‡•å‡§§‡•Ä ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ì‡§∞, ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§à ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ï ‡§™‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡§ï ‡§™‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ö ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§à ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§∞‡§π‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§®‡§®‡•á, ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§¨‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- While some weak firms did close down, the overall impact was not just making them weaker or shutting them all down. It spurred a process of restructuring and modernization.
- It encouraged private companies, not banned them.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§õ ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ã‡§∞ ‡§´‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ó‡§à‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤ ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ã‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§â‡§® ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§†‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
- ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The impact of globalisation on Indian industry was transformative, acting as both a challenge and an opportunity that separated the efficient firms from the inefficient ones.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ö‡•Å‡§®‡•å‡§§‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•ã‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤ ‡§´‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤ ‡§´‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ó ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- Several Indian companies, such as Tata Motors, Mahindra & Mahindra, and Infosys, successfully leveraged the opportunities of globalisation to become multinational corporations themselves.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§ü‡§æ‡§ü‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§∏, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§è‡§Ç‡§° ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§á‡§Ç‡§´‡•ã‡§∏‡§ø‡§∏ ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§à ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§®‡•á ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§¶ ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ ‡§¨‡§®‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§´‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠ ‡§â‡§†‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§

question: Q.136) Which sector was the largest contributor to India's GDP between 1947 and 1991?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Throughout the pre-reform period (1947-1991), despite the policy focus on industrialization, the agricultural sector remained the largest contributor to India's GDP. Its share, while declining gradually from over 50% in 1950, remained higher than that of both the industrial and service sectors for most of this period. It was only around the late 1980s and early 1990s that the service sector started to catch up and eventually overtake agriculture.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

question: Q.137) At the time of independence, India's economy was predominantly:

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- This is a fundamental characteristic of the Indian economy in 1947. The economy was overwhelmingly dominated by the agricultural sector. The vast majority of the population (around 75%) lived in villages and derived their livelihood from agriculture and related activities. The contribution of this sector to the national income was also the largest (over 50%).

question: Q.138) Infrastructure development is essential for sustaining high growth and reducing regional disparities. Which of the following sectors is NOT typically included in the core infrastructure sectors in India?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The 'core infrastructure sectors' in India usually refer to a specific list of industries that are considered critical for the economy's functioning and whose performance is tracked closely (e.g., in the Index of Eight Core Industries). This list includes sectors like Electricity, Steel, Cement, Coal, Crude Oil, Natural Gas, Refinery Products, and Fertilizers. While tourism is an important service sector that relies on infrastructure, it is not itself considered a 'core' infrastructure industry in this specific technical sense.

question: Q.139) What was the main focus of India's Second Five Year Plan with respect to the economy?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Second Five-Year Plan (1956-1961) marked a decisive shift in India's development strategy. It was based on the Mahalanobis model, which advocated for rapid industrialisation with a strong focus on the development of capital-intensive, basic and heavy industries. The idea was to build a strong industrial base that could produce capital goods (like machinery) domestically, which would then support the growth of other sectors in the long run.

question: Q.140) Which of the following is the largest source of electricity generation in India?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Thermal power, primarily generated by burning coal, is the largest source of electricity in India. Despite a significant push towards renewable energy, coal-based power plants still account for the majority of India's installed electricity generation capacity and actual power production. This is due to India's large domestic coal reserves and the reliability of thermal power plants.

question: Q.381) What is the primary goal of zero-based budgeting (ZBB)?
options: To justify all expenditures from scratch
correct: To justify all expenditures from scratch

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: C) To justify all expenditures from scratch
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- **Zero-Based Budgeting (ZBB)** is a method where every expense must be justified for each new period. Unlike traditional budgeting which uses the previous year's budget as a baseline, ZBB starts from a 'zero base'. Every department has to justify its entire budget request in detail, proving why it needs the funds.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **A)** ZBB is forward-looking, not focused on tracking past expenses.
- **B) and D)** ZBB is a method for managing expenditure, not for increasing revenue.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- ZBB promotes efficiency and helps in eliminating wasteful expenditures, but it is also a very time-consuming process.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The concept of Zero-Based Budgeting was first developed at Texas Instruments Inc. in the late 1960s.

question: Q.142) Which sector was most affected by liberalisation in India?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- This is a nuanced question. While industry and services were the primary focus of the 1991 reforms and grew rapidly, the agricultural sector was arguably the 'most affected' in a negative or challenging sense. The reforms led to a reduction in public investment in agriculture, removal of subsidies on inputs like fertilizers, and increased exposure to volatile international markets. This, combined with other factors, led to a slowdown in agricultural growth and has been cited as a cause of agrarian distress in the post-reform period.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

question: Q.143) Between 1991 and 2020, India's export-import trends show:
options: Rising imports outpacing exports and widening the trade deficit
correct: Rising imports outpacing exports and widening the trade deficit

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Rising imports outpacing exports and widening the trade deficit.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§§‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ó‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤ ‡§∞‡§π‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ò‡§æ‡§ü‡•á ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ ‡§∞‡§π‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- In the post-reform period, both India's exports and imports grew dramatically, reflecting its integration with the global economy. However, for most of this period, the growth of merchandise imports has been faster than the growth of merchandise exports. This is largely due to India's heavy dependence on imported crude oil and growing demand for capital goods and electronics. As a result, India has consistently run a merchandise trade deficit (imports > exports), which has widened over time.

question: Q.144) Which of the following is NOT a component of India's core infrastructure sectors (as per Index of Eight Core Industries)?

‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Index of Eight Core Industries, which has a weight of 40.27% in the Index of Industrial Production (IIP), tracks the performance of the following eight sectors: Coal, Crude Oil, Natural Gas, Refinery Products, Fertilizers, Steel, Cement, and Electricity. While telecommunications is a critical infrastructure sector, it is not one of the eight industries included in this specific index.

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Automatic route for FDI.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§è‡§´‡§°‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Technology transfer is a key benefit of globalisation. One of the main channels for this is Foreign Direct Investment (FDI), where a foreign company invests in a domestic enterprise. To encourage this, governments create liberal FDI policies. The 'automatic route' for FDI is a policy where a foreign investor does not need prior approval from the government or RBI to make an investment in a particular sector. This policy makes it easier for foreign companies to invest, bringing with them not just capital but also advanced technology and management practices.

question: Q.146) How has globalisation helped India's exports?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Increased exports to other countries.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§π‡•Å‡§à‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Globalisation has significantly helped India's exports. By reducing trade barriers globally and integrating India into the world economy, it opened up new and larger markets for Indian goods and services. The inflow of foreign technology and capital made Indian industries more competitive, enabling them to produce goods of better quality at lower prices for the international market. The most dramatic success story has been the boom in software and IT service exports.

question: Q.147) Which government-owned organisation is primarily responsible for electricity transmission in India?
options: Power Grid Corporation of India Limited
correct: Power Grid Corporation of India Limited

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- POWERGRID is a central Public Sector Undertaking and India's largest electric power transmission utility. It is responsible for the planning, implementation, operation, and maintenance of the inter-state transmission system and the national grid. It transmits about 50% of the total power generated in India on its transmission network.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§™‡•â‡§µ‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§° ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§¨‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§£ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞-‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§° ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§®, ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§ñ‡§∞‡§ñ‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ú‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§£ ‡§®‡•á‡§ü‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§ø‡§ú‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ó‡§≠‡§ó 50% ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **NTPC** (National Thermal Power Corporation) is primarily involved in electricity *generation*.
- **BHEL** (Bharat Heavy Electricals Limited) is a manufacturer of power plant equipment.
- The **CEA** (Central Electricity Authority) is a statutory organization that advises the government on technical and policy matters related to electricity.

- **‡§¨‡•Ä‡§è‡§ö‡§à‡§è‡§≤** (‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§π‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§á‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ü‡•á‡§°) ‡§¨‡§ø‡§ú‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

- A strong and reliable national transmission grid, managed by POWERGRID, is essential for ensuring that electricity generated in one part of the country can be supplied to demand centers across India.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§™‡•â‡§µ‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§° ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§¨‡•Ç‡§§ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§° ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§π‡•à ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§¨‡§ø‡§ú‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ï‡•á‡•§

question: Q.148) Which of the following was a major fiscal reform introduced in India as part of the 1991 economic reforms?
options: Introduction of the Modified Value Added Tax
correct: Introduction of the Modified Value Added Tax

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Introduction of the Modified Value Added Tax (MODVAT).

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞ (MODVAT) ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§Ø‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The 1991 reforms included a major overhaul of the tax system, based on the recommendations of the Raja Chelliah Committee. A key reform in the indirect tax structure was the rationalization and expansion of the Modified Value Added Tax (MODVAT) scheme. MODVAT was a system that allowed manufacturers to claim credit for the excise duty paid on inputs, thereby reducing the cascading effect (tax on tax) of indirect taxes. This was a crucial step towards the eventual implementation of a full-fledged Value Added Tax (VAT) and later, the GST.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§ö‡•á‡§≤‡•à‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§ø‡§´‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§´‡•á‡§∞‡§¨‡§¶‡§≤ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞ (MODVAT) ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ MODVAT ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ê‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§•‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§á‡§®‡§™‡•Å‡§ü ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§è ‡§ó‡§è ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§°‡§ø‡§ü ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡•Ä ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ (‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞) ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ï‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞ (VAT) ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, GST ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§ï‡§¶‡§Æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The tax reforms of 1991 aimed to create a simpler, more transparent, and more efficient tax system to support the newly liberalised economy.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§à ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§∞‡§≤, ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The MODVAT scheme was first introduced on a limited basis in 1986 but was significantly expanded and strengthened as part of the 1991 reforms.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- MODVAT ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞ 1986 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§à ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§® 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§á‡§∏‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§¨‡•Ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§

question: Q.149) Which index combines life expectancy, education and per capita income to measure a country's human development?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite statistical tool created by the United Nations to measure and rank countries based on their level of social and economic development. It is based on three key dimensions of human development: a long and healthy life (measured by life expectancy), knowledge (measured by years of schooling), and a decent standard of living (measured by GNI per capita).

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï (‡§è‡§ö‡§°‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à) ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§â‡§®‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∞‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡•Ä‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•à: ‡§è‡§ï ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¨‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§• ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® (‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à), ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® (‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à), ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§è‡§®‡§Ü‡§à ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à)‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The HDI provides a more holistic measure of a country's development than purely economic indicators like GDP.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§è‡§ö‡§°‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§°‡•Ä‡§™‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.150) The Planning Commission was the apex body responsible for formulating Five-Year Plans. In which year was the Planning Commission of India established?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Planning Commission of India was established in March 1950 by a resolution of the Government of India. It was set up to formulate India's Five-Year Plans for social and economic development, based on the model of centralised planning adopted by the country after independence.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö 1950 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§à ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§è ‡§ó‡§è ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡•â‡§°‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§§‡•à‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- 1951 was the year the First Five-Year Plan was launched, but the commission itself was established a year earlier.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- 1951 ‡§µ‡§π ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡§¨ ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§à ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§® ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- For over 60 years, the Planning Commission played a central role in steering the Indian economy, until it was replaced by the NITI Aayog in 2015.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- 60 ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ï, ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§®‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§à, ‡§ú‡§¨ ‡§§‡§ï ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§á‡§∏‡•á 2015 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The Planning Commission was an advisory body and was not created by the Constitution or by an Act of Parliament.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§≤‡§æ‡§π‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§•‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§® ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§

question: Q.382) What was India's reform model described as, in contrast to the 'shock therapy' of Eastern Europe?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- In contrast to the 'shock therapy' (rapid, all-at-once shift to a market economy) seen in some Eastern European countries, India's economic reforms of 1991 are widely described as a **gradualist** approach. India introduced reforms in a phased and sequential manner, carefully opening up different sectors over time. This approach of **'gradualist stabilisation'** was seen as more suitable for a large democracy.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The other terms describe different economic concepts not relevant to the style of India's reforms.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The debate between 'shock therapy' versus 'gradualism' is a central theme in development economics, and India is often cited as a successful case study of the gradualist approach.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- Dr. Manmohan Singh's famous quote, "No power on earth can stop an idea whose time has come," was delivered in his 1991 budget speech, launching the reforms.

question: Q.151) Which of the following was NOT a feature of the Green Revolution in India?
options: Increased use of fertilisers and irrigation

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Expansion of agricultural land.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Green Revolution was an 'intensive' agricultural strategy, not an 'extensive' one. This means it focused on increasing productivity *per unit of land* rather than bringing more land under cultivation. The core of the revolution was the use of a technology package‚ÄîHYV seeds, fertilizers, irrigation, and machinery‚Äîon existing agricultural land to dramatically boost yields.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§è‡§ï '‡§ó‡§π‡§®' ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§∞‡§£‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø '‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï'‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§§‡§≤‡§¨ ‡§π‡•à ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§ñ‡•á‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡§π‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø *‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ü ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø* ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤ ‡§Æ‡•å‡§ú‡•Ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡•à‡§ï‡•á‡§ú - HYV ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú, ‡§â‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï, ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§à ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§®‡§∞‡•Ä - ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•à‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The use of high-yielding variety (HYV) seeds, increased application of chemical fertilizers, expansion of irrigation, and mechanization (use of tractors, pumps, etc.) were all defining features of the Green Revolution.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§â‡§™‡§ú ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ (HYV) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§â‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§§‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó, ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§à ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞, ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ (‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§ü‡§∞, ‡§™‡§Ç‡§™, ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó) ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡§è‡§Ç ‡§•‡•Ä‡§Ç‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The success of the Green Revolution in increasing food production without a significant expansion of cultivated area was its greatest achievement.

explanation.fact:

- Before the Green Revolution, increases in food production in India largely came from expanding the area under cultivation, a strategy that had reached its limits by the 1960s.

question: Q.152) What three-part economic strategy defined India's policy changes in the 1990s?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Liberalisation, Privatisation and Globalisation (LPG).

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£, ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ (‡§è‡§≤‡§™‡•Ä‡§ú‡•Ä)‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The New Economic Policy launched in 1991 is famously known by the acronym LPG, which stands for:
  - **Liberalisation:** Reducing government controls and regulations to give more freedom to the private sector.
  - **Privatisation:** Transferring ownership of public sector enterprises to the private sector.
  - **Globalisation:** Integrating the Indian economy with the world economy.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 1991 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§à ‡§®‡§à ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á LPG ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§π‡•à:
  - **‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£:** ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡•§
  - **‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£:** ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡•§
  - **‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£:** ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§• ‡§è‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Nationalisation, Regulation, and Protectionism describe the pre-1991 policy regime that the LPG reforms sought to change.
- The other options describe broader processes but do not capture the specific three-pronged strategy of the 1991 reforms.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶ 1991 ‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡§§ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§è‡§≤‡§™‡•Ä‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§®‡•á ‡§¨‡§¶‡§≤‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§ï‡•Ä‡•§
- ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§® 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø-‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§£‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ï‡§°‡§º‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- This LPG model was part of a 'Structural Adjustment Program' which was a condition for the bailout loan India received from the IMF in 1991.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§è‡§≤‡§™‡•Ä‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•â‡§°‡§≤ ‡§è‡§ï '‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ' ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ã 1991 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§à‡§è‡§Æ‡§è‡§´ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡•á ‡§¨‡•á‡§≤‡§Ü‡§â‡§ü ‡§ã‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§§ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§

question: Q.153) Why is infrastructure referred to as the 'wheels' of economic growth?
options: It enables delivery of goods, services and access.
It is part of international trade.
correct: It enables delivery of goods, services and access.

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: It enables delivery of goods, services and access.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ì‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The analogy of 'wheels' is used because infrastructure (transport, communication, power) is what allows the entire economy to move and function. Just as wheels enable a vehicle to move, infrastructure enables the smooth flow of goods (via roads, ports), services and information (via communication networks), and factors of production like labor and capital. It provides the critical connectivity and access that underpins all economic activity.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- '‡§™‡§π‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç' ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§á‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§¨‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§¢‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ (‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡§®, ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞, ‡§¨‡§ø‡§ú‡§≤‡•Ä) ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏ ‡§§‡§∞‡§π ‡§™‡§π‡§ø‡§è ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§® ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ö‡§≤‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç, ‡§â‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§§‡§∞‡§π ‡§¨‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§¢‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ì‡§Ç (‡§∏‡§°‡§º‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç, ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§ó‡§æ‡§π‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•á), ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ (‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡•á‡§ü‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•á), ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§® ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§π ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§ï‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- While infrastructure is linked to international trade and can influence inflation, its most fundamental role is enabling the basic functioning and delivery mechanisms of the economy.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§¢‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ú‡•Å‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü ‡§π‡•à ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§¨‡§∏‡•á ‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ú ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§£ ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- Without adequate infrastructure, economic growth is severely constrained, which is why governments prioritize infrastructure development.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§¢‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡§æ, ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§Ø‡§π‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ú‡§π ‡§π‡•à ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§¢‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- Infrastructure projects often have a high 'multiplier effect', meaning that every rupee spent on infrastructure generates more than one rupee of additional GDP.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø
