question: Q.155) What was the major aim of India's 1991 economic reforms?
options: To reduce taxes on luxury goods

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The 1991 reforms were launched in response to a severe macroeconomic crisis. The immediate aim was stabilization, which involved controlling high inflation and correcting the critical balance of payments deficit. The broader and long-term aim was to put the economy on a path of high and sustainable growth by undertaking structural reforms (the LPG agenda). Therefore, stabilizing the crisis-ridden economy was the most immediate and major aim.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§á‡§ï‡•â‡§®‡•â‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§¨ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§è ‡§ó‡§è ‡§•‡•á‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§® ‡§ò‡§æ‡§ü‡•á ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§†‡•Ä‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ (‡§è‡§≤‡§™‡•Ä‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ú‡•á‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ) ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§§‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§• ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§è, ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§¨‡§∏‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:

- The reforms aimed to *reduce*, not increase, government control.
- They aimed to *privatise*, not nationalise, companies.

- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•à‡§ï‡•á‡§ú ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç‡•§

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¶‡•ã-‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§£ ‡§•‡§æ: ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§∏‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§ü‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø, ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•§

question: Q.156) Tertiary activities are also known as the:

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The economy is broadly classified into three sectors. The primary sector involves the extraction of raw materials. The secondary sector involves manufacturing. The tertiary sector involves the provision of services rather than end products. Therefore, 'tertiary sector' and 'service sector' are used interchangeably.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ü‡•á ‡§§‡•å‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§§‡•Ä‡§® ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§® ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§è, '‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞' ‡§î‡§∞ '‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞' ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The **agricultural sector** is the primary sector.
- The **industrial sector** is the secondary sector.
- The **health sector** is *an example* of a service sector activity, but 'service sector' is the broader, synonymous term for all tertiary activities.

explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The service sector includes a wide range of activities, from a local barber shop to a multinational software company.

- ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§à ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§® ‡§∏‡•á ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•â‡§´‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•á‡§Ø‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡•Ä ‡§§‡§ï ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•É‡§Ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.157) Which of the following factors has least contributed to rural distress in India?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: High rural literacy levels.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- High literacy levels are a positive factor that helps *alleviate* distress, not contribute to it. Better literacy can help farmers adopt new technologies, access financial services, and find non-farm employment. While rural literacy in India is not uniformly high, it is a positive development and not a cause of distress.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï ‡§π‡•à ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§â‡§∏‡•á *‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á* ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§¶ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§¨‡•á‡§π‡§§‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§à ‡§§‡§ï‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•á, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ï ‡§™‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ö‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ó‡•à‡§∞-‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§¶ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à, ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§π‡•à ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **Declining productivity**, especially in rainfed areas dependent on monsoons, is a major cause of low and uncertain farm incomes.
- **Shortages of post-harvest infrastructure** (like cold storage and warehouses) lead to high wastage and prevent farmers from getting good prices.
- **Fragmentation of land holdings** (land being divided into smaller and smaller plots) makes farming uneconomical and inefficient. These are all major, well-known causes of rural distress.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- **‡§ò‡§ü‡§§‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡§§‡§æ**, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- **‡§ï‡§ü‡§æ‡§à ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§¢‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á** (‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§° ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§ú ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ó‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ) ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•á ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¨‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- **‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ã‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡§Ç‡§°‡§®** (‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§õ‡•ã‡§ü‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§õ‡•ã‡§ü‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ñ‡§Ç‡§°‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•ã‡§®‡§æ) ‡§ñ‡•á‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- Rural distress in India is a complex problem with multiple interconnected causes, including agricultural, economic, and social factors.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ú‡§ü‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§à ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•Å‡§°‡§º‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø, ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- Over 85% of farmers in India are classified as small and marginal farmers, with landholdings of less than two hectares.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç 85% ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§õ‡•ã‡§ü‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•ã‡§§ ‡§¶‡•ã ‡§π‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§Ø‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.312) Which major reform was aimed at redistributing land to the landless after independence?

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: D) Land Ceiling Acts
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- After independence, a key part of India's land reform program was the imposition of land ceilings. Land Ceiling Acts were passed by various states to fix a maximum limit on the amount of land that an individual or family could own. The surplus land above this ceiling was to be acquired by the government and redistributed among landless laborers and small farmers.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **A) The Green Revolution** was a technological reform to increase productivity. **B) and C)** are different agricultural policies, not focused on redistribution.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- While the idea was revolutionary, the implementation of land ceiling acts was largely unsuccessful due to numerous loopholes, benami transfers, and a lack of political will, resulting in very little surplus land actually being redistributed.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- Another major land reform was the abolition of the Zamindari system, which aimed to eliminate the intermediary landlords.

question: Q.383) What was the impact of liberalisation on the automobile industry in India after 1991?
options: It stimulated the demand for vehicles in the market, leading to healthy growth of the industry.
It led to a decline in the demand for vehicles.
It had no impact on the industry.
It only benefited the passenger car segment.
correct: It stimulated the demand for vehicles in the market, leading to healthy growth of the industry.

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: A) It stimulated the demand for vehicles in the market, leading to healthy growth of the industry.
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Liberalisation delicensed the industry and allowed FDI. This led to the entry of global automakers, bringing in new technology, increased competition, and a wide variety of models. This, combined with rising incomes, **stimulated demand and led to the phenomenal growth** of the entire industry.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **B and C** are incorrect; the impact was massive and positive.
- **D** is incorrect because the two-wheeler and commercial vehicle segments also experienced huge growth.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The automobile sector is often considered a poster child for the success of India's 1991 economic reforms.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- Before 1991, India had primarily three passenger car manufacturers: Hindustan Motors (Ambassador), Premier Automobiles (Padmini), and Maruti Udyog.

question: Q.384) What was the primary goal for nationalising private insurance companies in the pre-reform era?
options: Pool long-term funds for planned development
correct: Pool long-term funds for planned development

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: C) Pool long-term funds for planned development
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The nationalisation of the life insurance sector (creating LIC in 1956) and general insurance (in 1972) was done to **pool the vast long-term funds** collected as premiums and channel them towards national development projects as laid out in the Five-Year Plans, particularly in infrastructure and the public sector.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **Boost competition** is the opposite of the goal; nationalisation created a state monopoly.
- While **protecting consumer rights** was a stated objective, the main economic goal was resource mobilization for development.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The nationalisation of insurance was driven by the state's desire to have greater control over the nation's financial resources for planned developmental objectives.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The insurance sector in India was reopened to private participation in the year 2000, ending the state monopoly.

question: Q.385) When was the Market Stabilisation Scheme (MSS) introduced for durable liquidity management?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Market Stabilisation Scheme (MSS) was introduced by the RBI in **April 2004**. It was created to manage the massive and sustained surge in capital inflows into India during the early 2000s, allowing the RBI to absorb this excess liquidity from the banking system in a durable way.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The other years are incorrect. The scheme was a direct response to the specific economic conditions of the mid-2000s.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- MSS is a crucial sterilization tool that allows the central bank to manage liquidity arising from external sources without impacting the government's fiscal deficit.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- Funds collected under MSS are held in a separate cash account with the RBI and are not available for the government's regular spending.

question: Q.386) Which of the following is a tool used by the RBI to control inflation through monetary policy?

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: D) Reverse repo rate
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The **Reverse Repo Rate** is a key tool of monetary policy. It is the rate at which the RBI absorbs liquidity from commercial banks. To control inflation, the RBI would increase the reverse repo rate, encouraging banks to park more funds with the RBI. This reduces the money supply in the economy, curbs spending, and helps control inflation.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **Fiscal deficit, income tax rate, and subsidy allocation** are all instruments of **Fiscal Policy**, managed by the Government, not the RBI.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- Monetary policy (managed by RBI) uses interest rates and liquidity tools, while fiscal policy (managed by government) uses taxation and public expenditure.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The corridor between the Repo Rate (lending rate) and the Reverse Repo Rate (absorption rate) acts as the policy corridor for short-term money market interest rates.

question: Q.387) Which of the following is correct regarding the New Industrial Policy announced in July 1991?
options: It banned FDI in manufacturing and core industries.
It expanded the scope of licensing for all industries.
It de-reserved several industries previously earmarked for the public sector.
It introduced a five-year industrial licensing review mechanism.
correct: It de-reserved several industries previously earmarked for the public sector.

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: C) It de-reserved several industries previously earmarked for the public sector.
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- A major component of the New Industrial Policy of 1991 was to reduce the dominance of the public sector. It drastically reduced the number of industries exclusively reserved for the public sector from 17 to 8 (and later even fewer). This process of **de-reservation** opened up many critical areas to private and foreign investment.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **A)** It did the opposite; it liberalized the FDI regime.
- **B)** It did the opposite; it abolished industrial licensing for most industries (the 'License Raj').
- **D)** No such mechanism was part of this policy.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The 1991 Industrial Policy marked a radical departure from the earlier state-led industrialization strategy.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- Currently, only two sectors are reserved for the public sector: atomic energy and railway operations.

question: Q.388) Which of the following policies replaced the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act (FERA) during the economic reforms in the Indian Economy?
options: FIAC ‚Äì Foreign Investment and Audit Code

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: D) FEMA ‚Äì Foreign Exchange Management Act
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The stringent Foreign Exchange Regulation Act (FERA) of 1973 was repealed and replaced by the more liberal **Foreign Exchange Management Act (FEMA)** in 1999. FEMA took a facilitative approach, aiming to manage foreign exchange and promote the orderly development of the forex market, rather than just controlling it.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The other options are fictitious acronyms.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The transition from FERA to FEMA was a crucial legislative change that symbolized India's shift from a regime of forex control to forex management.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- Under FERA, the principle was 'everything is prohibited unless permitted', whereas under FEMA, it is 'everything is permitted unless prohibited'.

question: Q.389) Which of the following policy reforms in 1991 significantly reduced the industrial licensing requirements, leading to increased industrial output?

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: B) New Industrial Policy
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The centerpiece of the 1991 economic reforms was the **New Industrial Policy**. Its most dramatic feature was the abolition of the industrial licensing system ('License Raj'). By removing this requirement for most industries, the policy unleashed entrepreneurial energy, reduced bureaucratic hurdles, and directly led to increased industrial output.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **Green Revolution** (1960s) related to agriculture.
- **SEZ Policy** (2000) and **Make in India** (2014) were later initiatives.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The dismantling of the License Raj is considered the single most important reform that transformed the Indian industrial landscape.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- After 1991, industrial licensing was retained only for a short list of industries related to security, strategic, and environmental concerns.

question: Q.390) Which Plan saw the launch of the Twenty-Point Programme and increased politicisation of the planning process?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The **Fifth Five-Year Plan (1974-1979)** was launched during a politically charged era under Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. In 1975, during this plan, the **Twenty-Point Programme** was launched, focusing on poverty alleviation ('Garibi Hatao'). The period coincided with the National Emergency, leading to what analysts describe as an increased politicisation of the planning process.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The other plans are associated with different time periods and policy priorities.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The Fifth Plan is notable for its focus on poverty removal and self-reliance. It was also uniquely terminated one year early in 1978 by the new Janata Party government.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The Twenty-Point Programme has been restructured multiple times since its launch, with revised versions in 1982, 1986, and 2006.

question: Q.391) Which sector saw a significant boost due to economic reforms initiated in 1991, particularly noted for contributing to industrial growth?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The economic reforms of 1991, including deregulation and opening up of telecommunications, created a highly favorable environment for the **IT sector**. The availability of an educated, English-speaking workforce allowed Indian companies to tap into the global demand for software services. The IT sector experienced explosive growth, becoming a major contributor to India's exports and GDP.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- While other sectors also benefited, the growth of the IT sector was unprecedented and transformative.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The rise of India's IT and software services industry is one of the most celebrated success stories of the post-1991 economic reform era.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The establishment of Software Technology Parks of India (STPI) in 1991, which provided high-speed data links, played a crucial role in enabling software exports.

question: Q.490) The Government of India formally proposed the Second Green Revolution in which year?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The idea of a **Second Green Revolution** was formally articulated in India's **National Agriculture Policy**, which was announced in the year **2000**. The policy aimed to build upon the successes of the first Green Revolution by promoting sustainable agriculture, diversification, and the use of biotechnology.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The other years are incorrect. The policy framework was laid down in 2000.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- While the first Green Revolution focused on food grain self-sufficiency, the Second Green Revolution aims for sustainable and holistic agricultural development.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The term 'Evergreen Revolution' was coined by Dr. M.S. Swaminathan to emphasize the need for increasing productivity in perpetuity without ecological harm.

question:
Q.366) Which of the given statements is/are INCORRECT regarding the five year plans of India?
1. The First Five-Year Plan prioritised agricultural development to address food security.
2. The First Five-Year Plan was based on Harrod-Domar Model.

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: D) Neither Statement 1 nor Statement 2
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

The question asks which statement is **INCORRECT**. Both statements provided are actually **CORRECT**.

- **Statement 1:** Correct. The First Five-Year Plan (1951-1956) was launched post-partition amid severe food shortages, so its primary focus was on developing the agricultural sector.
- **Statement 2:** Correct. The plan was based on the Harrod-Domar model, which emphasized the role of savings and capital investment in economic growth.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Since both statements are correct, the correct response is that *neither* statement is incorrect.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The First Five-Year Plan successfully achieved its growth targets and laid the groundwork for future industrialization.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The allocation for irrigation and energy in the First Plan was higher than the allocation for agriculture itself, showing the focus on ancillary sectors.

question: Q.491) What is the primary objective of the eGramSwaraj portal?
options: To improve transportation in rural areas
To enhance transparency in planning, reporting, and accounting of PRIs
To monitor urban development projects, and improve transportation in rural areas
To promote online education in villages
correct: To enhance transparency in planning, reporting, and accounting of PRIs

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: B) To enhance transparency in planning, reporting, and accounting of PRIs
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- **eGramSwaraj** is a web portal launched by the Ministry of Panchayati Raj. Its primary objective is to bring transparency and accountability to the functioning of Panchayati Raj Institutions (PRIs). It serves as a single platform for **decentralized planning, progress reporting, and work-based accounting**.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The portal's focus is on the governance and financial management of Panchayats, not transportation or education specifically.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- eGramSwaraj is a key initiative under the e-Panchayat Mission Mode Project, aiming to digitize the functioning of PRIs.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The portal was launched on National Panchayati Raj Day, April 24, 2020.

question: Q.492) Which of the following best explains the theoretical foundation of the design of the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA)?

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: C) Keynesian demand-side rural stimulus model
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- MGNREGA's design is rooted in **Keynesian economic principles**. It acts as a **demand-side stimulus** by guaranteeing employment, which puts purchasing power into the hands of the rural poor. This increases aggregate demand, helping to stimulate the rural economy, especially during lean seasons or economic distress. It is a classic counter-cyclical policy.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **Supply-side** policies focus on production. **Monetarist** principles focus on controlling money supply. These do not capture the core 'demand-boosting' mechanism of MGNREGA.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- MGNREGA combines poverty alleviation with macroeconomic stabilization through demand generation.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- MGNREGA is the largest social security scheme in the world, legally guaranteeing 100 days of wage employment to every rural household.

question: Q.493) Which of the following initiatives was introduced in 2014 to boost the industrial sector by making India a global manufacturing hub?

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: D) Make in India
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The **'Make in India'** initiative was launched on September 25, **2014**, with the primary objective of transforming India into a **global design and manufacturing hub**. It aims to encourage companies to manufacture their products in India by improving the ease of doing business.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **Skill India** (2015) focuses on vocational training. **National Manufacturing Policy** was launched earlier in 2011. **Atal Innovation Mission** focuses on innovation.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- 'Make in India' is a flagship program aimed at increasing the manufacturing sector's contribution to the GDP.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The logo of the 'Make in India' initiative is a lion made of cogwheels, symbolizing India's strength and progress in manufacturing.

question: Q.494) Which of the following initiatives was launched to promote self-reliance among rural women by providing them with skills and financial assistance in India?
options: Deen Dayal Antyodaya Yojana - National Rural Livelihoods Mission
correct: Deen Dayal Antyodaya Yojana - National Rural Livelihoods Mission

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: B) Deen Dayal Antyodaya Yojana - National Rural Livelihoods Mission
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The **Deen Dayal Antyodaya Yojana - National Rural Livelihoods Mission (DAY-NRLM)** is a poverty alleviation program that mobilizes rural poor women into **Self-Help Groups (SHGs)**. The mission provides them with training, capacity building, and access to credit, empowering them to start their own livelihood activities.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **NRHM** focuses on healthcare. **BharatNet** focuses on broadband connectivity. **Skill India** is a broader skilling initiative.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- DAY-NRLM is one of the world's largest initiatives for improving the livelihoods of the poor, with a strong focus on women's empowerment.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- DAY-NRLM was formerly known as the Swarnajayanti Gram Swarozgar Yojana (SGSY).

question: Q.495) Which of the following programmes was launched in 2000 to improve cold storage facilities for agricultural products in India?

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: A) Grameen Bhandaran Yojana
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The **Grameen Bhandaran Yojana** (Rural Godown Scheme) was launched in the early 2000s. Its objective was to create scientific storage capacity in rural areas to prevent distress sales and post-harvest losses. A key component was providing subsidies for the construction of **cold storage facilities** for perishable agricultural produce.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **PMFBY** is a crop insurance scheme. **NHM** (2005) and **RKVY** (2007) are broader schemes that also support cold storage, but the specific scheme from that era is the Grameen Bhandaran Yojana.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- Developing a robust cold chain infrastructure is critical for India's food security and for increasing farmers' income.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The scheme was credit-linked and implemented through NABARD and commercial banks, providing back-ended subsidies.

question: Q.497) According to the Union Budget 2024-25, what is the percentage increase in the government's estimated total expenditure for 2024-25, compared to the actual expenditure of 2023-24?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Union Budget for 2024-25 was an interim budget. The total expenditure was estimated at ‚Çπ47.66 lakh crore. This represented a modest increase of about **6.1%** over the Revised Estimates for the previous year (2023-24), which were ‚Çπ44.90 lakh crore. The government's focus on fiscal consolidation meant keeping the expenditure growth in check.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The other percentages are not accurate for the budgeted growth, which reflected a path of fiscal prudence.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- Budget figures, especially the growth in total and capital expenditure, are key indicators of the government's fiscal stance.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- A key highlight of the 2024-25 interim budget was the continued focus on capital expenditure (capex), which was increased by 11.1% to ‚Çπ11.11 lakh crore.

question: Q.498) Under the new income tax regime proposed in the Union Budget 2024-25, what is the increased standard deduction for salaried individuals and pensioners?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The **Union Budget 2023-24** introduced a standard deduction of **‚Çπ50,000** for salaried individuals and pensioners under the New Tax Regime, making it more attractive. The **Interim Budget 2024-25** did not propose any changes to the tax slabs or deductions, so the standard deduction remains at ‚Çπ50,000.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The other figures are incorrect. The standard deduction is a flat ‚Çπ50,000 for both the old and new tax regimes (for eligible taxpayers).
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The introduction of the standard deduction was a key change to make the New Tax Regime, which is the default regime, more appealing to taxpayers.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The standard deduction is a flat deduction from salary income that can be claimed irrespective of the actual expenses incurred by the employee.

question: Q.499) What was the life expectancy at birth in India in 2022 according to the Human Development Report 2023-24?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The UNDP's Human Development Report (HDR) 2023-24, providing data for 2022, reported that India's **life expectancy at birth** had improved to **67.7 years**. This was an increase from 62.7 years in the previous report's data, showing a recovery post-COVID-19.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The other figures are incorrect as per this specific report.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- Life expectancy at birth is a key indicator of a nation's overall health and is one of the three dimensions of the Human Development Index (HDI).
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- In the same HDR 2023-24, India's rank in the Human Development Index improved by one position to 134 out of 193 countries.

question: Q.500) What was the urban unemployment rate in India for the period of April 2024 to December 2024 as per the PLFS (Periodic Labour Force Survey- Quaterly Bulletin)?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The question refers to a future period (April-Dec 2024), indicating it is based on the most recent data available at the time of exam creation. The Periodic Labour Force Survey (PLFS) data for the October-December 2023 quarter showed the urban unemployment rate for persons aged 15 and above had fallen to **6.5%**. This figure represents the current trend of declining urban unemployment post-pandemic.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The other figures represent rates from earlier periods, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic when unemployment was much higher.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The PLFS provides crucial high-frequency data on the employment situation, helping policymakers track the health of the labor market.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The female Labour Force Participation Rate (LFPR) in urban areas also saw an improvement, reaching 25.0% in the October-December 2023 quarter.

question: Q.501) Which strategic disinvestment in the aviation sector marked a significant move in the Indian government's privatisation efforts in the 21st century?
options: Merger of Indian Airlines with Air India
Sale of Air India to Tata Group
correct: Sale of Air India to Tata Group

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: D) Sale of Air India to Tata Group
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The **sale of the national carrier Air India** back to the **Tata Group** in January 2022 was a landmark event in India's history of privatization. It marked the successful strategic disinvestment of a major public sector undertaking and was a significant step in the government's policy of moving out of non-strategic businesses.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **Merger of Indian Airlines with Air India (2007):** This was a consolidation of two state-owned airlines, the opposite of privatization.
- **Jet Airways** was always a private airline; its issue was bankruptcy, not privatization.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The successful privatization of Air India was a major milestone for the government's disinvestment agenda.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The sale of Air India to the Tata Group was a historic homecoming, as the airline was originally founded by J.R.D. Tata in 1932 as Tata Airlines before being nationalized.

question: Q.367) According to the World Bank, what was the percentage of extreme poverty in India in 2019?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- According to a World Bank Policy Research Working Paper, the extreme poverty rate in India for 2019 was estimated to be **10.2%**. This represented a significant decline from 22.5% in 2011.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The other percentages are incorrect figures according to the report.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- While measurement methods vary, the consistent trend indicates a steady decline in extreme poverty in India over the past few decades.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The World Bank defines 'extreme poverty' as living on less than $2.15 per person per day (in 2017 purchasing power parity terms).

classification.subject: Economics
classification.subTopic: International Financial Bodies (IMF, World Bank, WTO)

question: Q.1: Which international organisation supports globalisation and free trade?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: WTO (World Trade Organization).

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: WTO (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§†‡§®)‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The World Trade Organization (WTO) is the only global international organization dealing with the rules of trade between nations. Its primary purpose is to ensure that trade flows as smoothly, predictably, and freely as possible, which directly promotes globalisation and free trade.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§†‡§® (WTO) ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ö ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§ü‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§†‡§® ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•à ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç, ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•ã, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ß‡•á ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **UNESCO** (United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization) focuses on promoting world peace and security through international cooperation in education, arts, sciences, and culture.
- **IMF** (International Monetary Fund) works to foster global monetary cooperation, secure financial stability, and facilitate international trade, but its core function is to provide financial assistance to countries with balance of payments problems, not to set trade rules.
- **WHO** (World Health Organization) is a specialized agency of the United Nations responsible for international public health.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- **‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã** (‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï, ‡§µ‡•à‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§†‡§®) ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ, ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- **IMF** (‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑) ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§π‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•á, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡§ï ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§® ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡•§
- **WHO** (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§†‡§®) ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§è‡§ú‡•á‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ú‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The WTO is the cornerstone of the modern global trading system, created to supervise and liberalize international trade.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- WTO ‡§Ü‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The WTO was established on January 1, 1995, succeeding the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), which was established in 1948.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- WTO ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡§æ 1 ‡§ú‡§®‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä, 1995 ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§π‡•Å‡§à ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡•ã 1948 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ü‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§´ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ù‡•å‡§§‡•á (GATT) ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡•§

question: Q.2: What is the projected annual growth rate of India-UK bilateral trade under the new Free Trade Agreement (FTA)?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Various economic analyses and reports released during the India-UK FTA negotiations have projected a significant boost to bilateral trade. The figure of a 15% annual growth rate is often cited as a potential outcome, reflecting the ambitious goals of the agreement to lower tariffs and non-tariff barriers across multiple sectors.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§-‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ü‡•á‡§® ‡§è‡§´‡§ü‡•Ä‡§è ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§ø‡§è ‡§ó‡§è ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§®‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ 15% ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§ï‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§ï‡§à ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ü‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§´ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ó‡•à‡§∞-‡§ü‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§´ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ù‡•å‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The other percentages represent different, less commonly cited projections or are inaccurate estimations of the FTA's expected impact.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§§ ‡§è‡§´‡§ü‡•Ä‡§è ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®, ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•É‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The India-UK Free Trade Agreement aims to double bilateral trade by 2030, making it a cornerstone of the strategic partnership between the two nations.

question: Q.3: Which of the following best describes the public sector's role in the Indian economy during 1947-1991?
options: Dominant in core and heavy industries
correct: Dominant in core and heavy industries

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Dominant in core and heavy industries.

The Industrial Policy Resolution of 1956 reserved strategic sectors, including core and heavy industries like steel, mining, machine tools, and defense, for public sector undertakings (PSUs) to build a strong industrial base.

question: Q.4: Which of the following best describes 'intergenerational equity'?
options: Fair distribution of resources among present-day nations
Fair allocation of resources among various income groups
Equal economic opportunities for all age-based population groups
Fair use of resources to ensure availability for future generations
correct: Fair use of resources to ensure availability for future generations

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Fair use of resources to ensure availability for future generations.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ä‡§¢‡§º‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§â‡§™‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Intergenerational equity is a concept of fairness or justice between generations. In an economic context, it is most commonly applied to the use of natural resources. It implies that the present generation should use resources in such a way that it does not compromise the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. This is a core principle of sustainable development.

- ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞-‡§™‡•Ä‡§¢‡§º‡•Ä‡§ó‡§§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ä‡§¢‡§º‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡§§‡•å‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ç ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§π‡•à ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§™‡•Ä‡§¢‡§º‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§§‡§∞‡§π ‡§∏‡•á ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§è ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ä‡§¢‡§º‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ù‡•å‡§§‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§§‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ 1 ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ 2 ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ 3 ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ä‡§¢‡§º‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ö ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§π‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§™‡•Ä‡§¢‡§º‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The concept of intergenerational equity is central to environmental policy and debates about climate change, resource depletion, and national debt.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞-‡§™‡•Ä‡§¢‡§º‡•Ä‡§ó‡§§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®, ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ã‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡•§

- The Brundtland Commission's 1987 report, 'Our Common Future', famously defined sustainable development as 'development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs,' popularizing the idea of intergenerational equity.

question: Q.5: What is used to measure a decent standard of living in HDI?
options: GDP per capita in PPP US Dollars
correct: GDP per capita in PPP US Dollars

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite index measuring average achievement in three key dimensions of human development: a long and healthy life, knowledge, and a decent standard of living. The standard of living is measured by Gross National Income (GNI) per capita, adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP) in US dollars. While GDP per capita is a close proxy and often used in explanations, GNI is the specific indicator.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï (HDI) ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡•Ä‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∏‡§§ ‡§â‡§™‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§π‡•à: ‡§è‡§ï ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¨‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§• ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®, ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•§ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§Ø (GNI) ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ (PPP) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§°‡•â‡§≤‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§ú‡§¨‡§ï‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§°‡•Ä‡§™‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•â‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§è‡§®‡§Ü‡§à ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ï ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Population density is a geographical measure, not a measure of standard of living.
- Availability of luxury goods is not a broad or reliable indicator of the average standard of living.
- Monthly salary does not account for non-wage income, purchasing power differences, or unpaid work.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ò‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§≠‡•å‡§ó‡•ã‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•§
- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§â‡§™‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§æ ‡§î‡§∏‡§§ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ï ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§® ‡§ó‡•à‡§∞-‡§Æ‡§ú‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§Ø, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§¨ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ñ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- HDI uses GNI per capita (PPP $) to provide a more comprehensive picture of a country's economic well-being and average standard of living than simple income metrics.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- HDI ‡§∏‡§∞‡§≤ ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§≠‡§≤‡§æ‡§à ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§î‡§∏‡§§ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø GNI (PPP $) ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The HDI was created by Pakistani economist Mahbub ul Haq in 1990 and has been used since then by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in its annual Human Development Report.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- HDI ‡§ï‡•ã 1990 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¨‡•Ç‡§¨ ‡§â‡§≤ ‡§π‡§ï ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§§‡§¨ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ (UNDP) ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.6: The National Multidimensional Poverty Index, published by NITI Aayog, measures poverty beyond income by considering multiple deprivations. Which of the following dimensions is NOT included in India's National Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI)?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- India's National MPI, like the global MPI, is based on three broad dimensions: Health, Education, and Standard of Living. These three dimensions are measured using a set of 12 indicators (e.g., nutrition, child mortality, years of schooling, cooking fuel, sanitation, etc.). Employment status is not one of the direct indicators or dimensions used in this framework, as the index aims to capture non-monetary deprivations.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø MPI, ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï MPI ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡§∞‡§π, ‡§§‡•Ä‡§® ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•à: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•§ ‡§á‡§® ‡§§‡•Ä‡§® ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã 12 ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡•á‡§ü ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à (‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è, ‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡§£, ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§¶‡§∞, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑, ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§à‡§Ç‡§ß‡§®, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ, ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø)‡•§ ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§¢‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§ø‡§è ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•à‡§∞-‡§Æ‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡§ï‡§°‡§º‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Health, Education, and Standard of Living are the three core dimensions that form the basis of the Multidimensional Poverty Index.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§§‡•Ä‡§® ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§®‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The MPI provides a more holistic view of poverty by capturing acute deprivations in health, education, and living standards that a person may face simultaneously, moving beyond a simple income-based poverty line.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- MPI ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§® ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡§ï‡§°‡§º‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§• ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§Ø-‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§∞‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The National MPI report by NITI Aayog is based on the data from the National Family Health Survey (NFHS).

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§è‡§Æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ (NFHS) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§ï‡§°‡§º‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.7: Which of the following was a major drawback of the Indian economy at the time of independence?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: High unemployment and poverty.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- At the time of independence in 1947, the Indian economy was characterized by severe underdevelopment. Centuries of colonial rule had led to a stagnant economy, widespread poverty, and high levels of unemployment and underemployment, particularly in rural areas. The per capita income was extremely low.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 1947 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§î‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§®‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä, ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- India was far from self-sufficient in food grains and often faced famines.
- The industrial sector was very small and underdeveloped ('de-industrialisation' had occurred under British rule).
- The infrastructure (railways, ports) was developed primarily to serve British colonial interests, not for the overall development of the country, and was thus inadequate.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞ ‡§π‡•ã‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§•‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
- ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ ‡§õ‡•ã‡§ü‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡§æ (‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ü‡§ø‡§∂ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡§π‡§§ '‡§µ‡§ø-‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£' ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü ‡§•‡§æ)‡•§
- ‡§¨‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§¢‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ (‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡§µ‡•á, ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§ó‡§æ‡§π) ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ü‡§ø‡§∂ ‡§î‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è, ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The post-independence government inherited a crippled economy, and its primary challenges were to alleviate poverty, build an industrial base, and achieve food security.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä, ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ö‡•Å‡§®‡•å‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ, ‡§è‡§ï ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- At the time of independence, about 70-75% of the country's population was dependent on agriculture, which contributed to only about 50% of the national income, indicating very low productivity.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø, ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§≤‡§ó‡§≠‡§ó 70-75% ‡§Ü‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞ ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤ 50% ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.8: Why can Gross Enrollment Ratio (GER) sometimes exceed 100%?
options: Due to school mergers in rural areas
Due to inclusion of post-graduate students
Due to enrollment of learners outside the official age group
Because of errors in census data
correct: Due to enrollment of learners outside the official age group

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Due to enrollment of learners outside the official age group.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§® ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Gross Enrollment Ratio (GER) is calculated as the total enrollment in a specific level of education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the official school-age population for that level. If there are students enrolled who are older or younger than the official age group (e.g., over-aged students repeating a grade or under-aged children starting early), the numerator (total enrollment) can become larger than the denominator (official age-group population), causing the GER to exceed 100%.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§® ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§§ (GER) ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§£‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§® ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ö‡§æ‡§π‡•á ‡§â‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§õ ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§π‡•ã, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§â‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤-‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§§ ‡§õ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•á ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§õ‡•ã‡§ü‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç (‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è, ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§â‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§õ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§° ‡§¶‡•ã‡§π‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∞‡§π‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§â‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§ú‡§≤‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§π‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç), ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§∂ (‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§®) ‡§π‡§∞ (‡§Ü‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å-‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§π ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä) ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§∏‡•á GER 100% ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- School mergers would not inherently increase the GER beyond 100%.
- GER is calculated for specific levels (primary, secondary, tertiary), so including post-graduates would be part of the tertiary GER, but it's the age discrepancy that pushes it over 100%.
- While census data errors can affect accuracy, they are not the structural reason why GER can conceptually exceed 100%.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á GER 100% ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡•á‡§ó‡§æ‡•§
- GER ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§£‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï, ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à, ‡§á‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï GER ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ, ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§® ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§â‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•à ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§á‡§∏‡•á 100% ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ä‡§™‡§∞ ‡§≤‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- ‡§ú‡§¨‡§ï‡§ø ‡§ú‡§®‡§ó‡§£‡§®‡§æ ‡§°‡•á‡§ü‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§ü‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç, ‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø GER ‡§µ‡•à‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á 100% ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- A GER above 100% indicates that a country is accommodating all of its school-age population and also students from other age groups, often reflecting efforts to increase access to education for all.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- 100% ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ä‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ GER ‡§á‡§Ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤-‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§π‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§õ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§π‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§§‡§ï ‡§™‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ö ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- To get a more precise picture of enrollment for the official age group, the Net Enrollment Ratio (NER) is used, which only considers children of the official school age. NER can never exceed 100%.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è, ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§® ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§§ (NER) ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§â‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ NER ‡§ï‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§≠‡•Ä 100% ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§π‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.9: In post 1991 reforms, the term 'disinvestment' refers to:
options: selling government's share in public sector companies
correct: selling government's share in public sector companies

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Disinvestment is the policy of the government liquidating its assets, primarily by selling its stake (shares) in Public Sector Undertakings (PSUs). This was a key component of the Privatisation policy under the 1991 economic reforms. The objectives include raising resources for the government, improving the efficiency of PSUs through private participation, and promoting wider public ownership.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡•á‡§ö‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•à, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç (PSUs) ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•Ä ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä (‡§∂‡•á‡§Ø‡§∞) ‡§¨‡•á‡§ö‡§ï‡§∞‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡§π‡§§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§ò‡§ü‡§ï ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§® ‡§ú‡•Å‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡§æ, ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡•Ä‡§è‡§∏‡§Ø‡•Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Increasing taxes is a fiscal policy measure related to revenue collection.
- Reducing foreign trade would be protectionism, the opposite of the liberalisation policy adopted in 1991.
- Reducing agricultural subsidies is another fiscal reform but is distinct from the concept of disinvestment.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§π‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ, ‡§ú‡•ã 1991 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§à ‡§ó‡§à ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§∏‡§¨‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§°‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§π‡•à ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§® ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ó ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- Disinvestment has been a consistent policy tool for successive Indian governments since 1991 to manage fiscal deficits and introduce market discipline in public sector enterprises.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- 1991 ‡§∏‡•á ‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ò‡§æ‡§ü‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§∞‡§π‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The Department of Investment and Public Asset Management (DIPAM) under the Ministry of Finance is the nodal agency for managing disinvestment in India.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

question: Q.368) As of 2021, what is India's estimated GDP, marking its growth since the reforms of 1991?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- According to data from the World Bank and IMF, India's nominal GDP crossed the $3 trillion mark in 2021, with **$3.1 trillion** being the widely accepted estimate. This represents a more than tenfold increase from its GDP of around $275 billion in 1991.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **$1 trillion** and **$2 trillion** were milestones India crossed in 2007 and 2014, respectively.
- **$5 trillion** is a future target for the Indian economy.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The journey from a sub-$300 billion economy in 1991 to over $3 trillion in three decades highlights the transformative impact of the 1991 economic reforms.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- In 1991, India's foreign exchange reserves had dwindled to just about $1.2 billion, enough to cover only about three weeks of imports.

question: Q.11: What significant change did the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) implement in 2025 regarding derivatives trading?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Introduction of limits on open positions in index options to reduce trading risks.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ú‡•ã‡§ñ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§á‡§Ç‡§°‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§ë‡§™‡•ç‡§∂‡§® ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ì‡§™‡§® ‡§™‡•ã‡§ú‡•Ä‡§∂‡§® ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§Ø‡•§

- As a market regulator, SEBI's role is to ensure market integrity and protect investors. Introducing limits on open positions (the number of open contracts a trader can hold) is a standard risk management measure. It prevents any single entity from accumulating an excessively large position that could manipulate the market or pose a systemic risk. This move in 2025 was aimed at curbing speculative activity and reducing overall market volatility.

question: Q.12: Which of the following statements regarding the estimation of India's national and per capita income during the colonial rule is correct?
options: The colonial government estimated India's national and per capita income sincerely every year.
The colonial government estimated India's per capita income but ignored national income.
The colonial government never made any sincere attempt to estimate India's national and per capita income.
The colonial government estimated India's national income but ignored per capita income.
correct: The colonial government never made any sincere attempt to estimate India's national and per capita income.

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: The colonial government never made any sincere attempt to estimate India's national and per capita income.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§î‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§à ‡§à‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- During British rule, there were no systematic or sincere official efforts to measure India's national income. The colonial administration's primary interest was in resource extraction and administration, not in assessing the overall economic welfare of the Indian population. The pioneering work in this field was done by Indian nationalists and economists like Dadabhai Naoroji, V.K.R.V. Rao, and R.C. Desai, who sought to highlight the economic drain and poverty caused by British rule.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

question: Q.13: At the time of independence, which sector contributed the largest share to India's national income?

- In 1947, the Indian economy was predominantly agrarian. question: Q.14: Which of the following is an example of soft infrastructure?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Infrastructure is broadly divided into two categories. 'Hard infrastructure' refers to the physical networks required for the functioning of a modern economy (e.g., roads, bridges, power plants). 'Soft infrastructure' refers to all the institutions and systems that are required to maintain the economic, health, social, and cultural standards of a country. This includes the education system, healthcare system, law enforcement, and financial institutions.

- ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§á‡§™‡§≤‡§æ‡§á‡§®‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§™‡•Å‡§≤ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§π‡§µ‡§æ‡§à ‡§Ö‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§≠‡•å‡§§‡§ø‡§ï, ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§á‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§° ‡§á‡§Ç‡§´‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§

It functioned as an advisory body to the government, responsible for formulating India's Five-Year Plans.

question: Q.17: Which sectors were emphasised in the Eighth Five-Year Plan for employment generation?
options: Animal husbandry, fishery, horticulture and rural industries
correct: Animal husbandry, fishery, horticulture and rural industries

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Animal husbandry, fishery, horticulture and rural industries.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§®, ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§®, ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Eighth Five-Year Plan (1992-1997) was launched immediately after the 1991 economic reforms. A key objective of this plan was employment generation, particularly in rural areas, to alleviate poverty. question: Q.18: Direct Tax reforms have been part of India's fiscal consolidation strategy. Which committee recommended the simplification of direct taxes in post-liberalisation India?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- In 2002, the Government of India constituted a task force on direct and indirect taxes under the chairmanship of Dr. Vijay Kelkar. The Kelkar Committee made wide-ranging recommendations for simplifying and rationalizing the tax structure, widening the tax base, and improving tax administration. Many of its recommendations have shaped India's tax policy over the years.

question: Q.20: Which sector was given top priority under the Second Five-Year Plan of India (1956-61)?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Heavy and basic industries.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Second Five-Year Plan was based on the Mahalanobis model, which advocated for a focus on rapid industrialization. The plan gave top priority to the development of heavy and basic industries, such as steel, heavy engineering, and machine tools, to build a strong, self-reliant industrial base. This strategy aimed to create capital goods domestically to support long-term growth.

question: Q.369) As per the Economic Survey, 2024-25, which of the following reflects a structural contradiction within India's rural employment strategy?
options: Skill training without matching rural job creation
High participation with low job card activation
Public works programmes coexisting with rising rural wages
Falling casual labour with rising self-employment
correct: Public works programmes coexisting with rising rural wages

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: C) Public works programmes coexisting with rising rural wages
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- This reflects a structural contradiction. Public works programs like MGNREGA are designed as 'employment of last resort' for times of distress. The fact that they coexist with **rising rural wages** suggests a disconnect. It implies that either market wages, though rising, are not sufficient or stable enough, or that the public works programs are creating upward pressure on wages.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- A, B, and D represent implementation challenges or labor market transitions, but not a fundamental structural contradiction in the same way.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- Analyzing the rural labor market reveals complex dynamics where government interventions and market forces interact in ways that can appear contradictory.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- Studies have shown that MGNREGA has increased the bargaining power of rural labor, leading to an overall increase in agricultural wages in many parts of India.

question: Q.21: Which Indian Prime Minister is closely associated with initiating the 1991 LPG reforms?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The landmark economic reforms of 1991, known as the LPG (Liberalisation, Privatisation, Globalisation) reforms, were initiated under the leadership of Prime Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao. He, along with his Finance Minister, Dr. Manmohan Singh, is credited with steering India away from a severe balance of payments crisis and putting it on a new path of high economic growth.

- **‡§á‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡•Ä** ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó ‡§ï‡§æ‡§´‡•Ä ‡§π‡§¶ ‡§§‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø-‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§

question: Q.22: Agricultural credit has grown significantly since liberalisation, though distribution remains uneven. Which institution is the apex body for rural credit in India?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: NABARD (National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development).

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§®‡§æ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§° (‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï)‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- NABARD was established in 1982 as an apex development bank. It is responsible for matters concerning policy, planning, and operations in the field of credit for agriculture and other economic activities in rural areas in India. question: Q.23: The term 'License Raj' is related to which sector of the Indian economy?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The term 'License Raj' refers to the elaborate system of licenses, regulations, and accompanying red tape that were required to set up and run businesses in India between the 1950s and 1991. This system was most pervasive in the industrial sector, where entrepreneurs needed government permission (a license) for almost every aspect of business, from starting a factory to expanding capacity or diversifying products.
