question: Q.24: Why is the iron and steel industry called a basic industry?
options: Because it provides essential raw materials, machinery, and tools to a wide range of other industries
Because it mainly produces household consumer items
Because it processes naturally available iron ores
Because it provides raw materials for other industries
correct: Because it provides raw materials for other industries

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Because it provides raw materials for other industries.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- A basic or key industry is one whose products are used as raw materials by many other industries. The iron and steel industry is considered basic because steel is a fundamental input for a vast array of other industries, including manufacturing (automobiles, machinery), construction (buildings, bridges), infrastructure (railways), and defense. The development of this industry is crucial for the overall industrial development of a country.

options: Selling government companies to private companies

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Selling government companies to private companies.

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Privatisation is the process of transferring the ownership, management, and control of public sector enterprises (PSUs) from the government to the private sector. This can be done either through disinvestment (selling a part of the government's equity) or by strategic sale (selling a majority stake to a private entity).

- Giving subsidies is a fiscal policy tool, not related to ownership of enterprises.

question: Q.26: Which economic system dominated India on the eve of independence (in 1947)?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- On the eve of independence, the Indian economy was fundamentally a colonial economy. Its structure was shaped by the needs of the British economy. It was predominantly agrarian, with a vast majority of the population engaged in low-productivity agriculture. Its industrial sector was underdeveloped, and its resources were exploited for the benefit of the colonial power.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§î‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ü‡§ø‡§∂ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§≤‡•á‡§§‡•Ä ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§® ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§î‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∂‡•ã‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- A socialist planned economy and import substitution industrialisation were policies adopted by India *after* independence.
- The economy was not a global free market; it was integrated with the world economy in a way that served British interests, with significant restrictions and exploitative trade patterns.

- ‡§î‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ù‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•á ‡§Ü‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ö‡•Å‡§®‡•å‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

üí° Interesting Fact

- British policies, such as the land revenue systems (Zamindari, Ryotwari), commercialization of agriculture, and destruction of traditional handicrafts, were major causes of the stagnation of the Indian economy.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ü‡§ø‡§∂ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç-‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä (‡§ú‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä, ‡§∞‡•à‡§Ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§º‡•Ä), ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£, ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§•‡•á‡•§

question: Q.27: Which sector(s) employed the largest share of the working population in India on the eve of independence?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The primary sector, which includes agriculture, forestry, fishing, and mining, was the largest employer in 1947. Approximately 70-75% of the Indian workforce was engaged in agriculture and allied activities. This reflected the underdeveloped and agrarian nature of the economy at that time.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø, ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä, ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ñ‡§®‡§® ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç, 1947 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¨‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ó‡§≠‡§ó 70-75% ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§â‡§∏ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The secondary sector (manufacturing, industry) and tertiary sector (services) were very small in terms of their share in both employment and national income.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ (‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£, ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó) ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ (‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§è‡§Ç) ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•ã‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•Ä ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ ‡§õ‡•ã‡§ü‡•á ‡§•‡•á‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- A key feature of economic development is the structural shift of the workforce from the primary sector to the secondary and tertiary sectors. While India has seen a shift in GDP contribution, a large proportion of the workforce remains in the primary sector.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§¨‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§ú‡§¨‡§ï‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤ ‡§ò‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡•Ç ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- Even today, the agriculture sector in India employs the largest number of people (around 45%), even though its contribution to GDP has fallen below 20%. This situation is often described as 'disguised unemployment'.

- ‡§Ü‡§ú ‡§≠‡•Ä, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¨‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ó (‡§≤‡§ó‡§≠‡§ó 45%) ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç, ‡§≠‡§≤‡•á ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§°‡•Ä‡§™‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§® 20% ‡§∏‡•á ‡§®‡•Ä‡§ö‡•á ‡§Ü ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ '‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä' ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.28: Which of the following instruments is primarily used by the RBI for monetary policy implementation in the post 1991 reform era?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- In the post-reform era, the RBI shifted from direct instruments of monetary control to indirect, market-based instruments. The Repo Rate, introduced under the Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF) in 2000, has become the main policy rate. By changing the repo rate (the rate at which it lends to commercial banks), the RBI influences the overall cost of funds in the economy, thereby managing liquidity and inflation.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§¨‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à ‡§Æ‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑, ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞-‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ì‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ 2000 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∞‡§≤‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§® ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ (LAF) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡§π‡§§ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§à ‡§∞‡•á‡§™‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡§§ ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§® ‡§ó‡§à ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§∞‡•á‡§™‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∞ (‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏ ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§â‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à) ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¶‡§≤‡§ï‡§∞, ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§¨‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§∏‡•á ‡§§‡§∞‡§≤‡§§‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Direct taxes, tariff rates, and export incentives are instruments of fiscal policy and trade policy, which are managed by the government, not the RBI.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§ï‡§∞, ‡§ü‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§´ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•á‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§è ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç, ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§¨‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The repo rate is a key tool in the RBI's inflation-targeting framework, signaling the central bank's stance on monetary policy.

- ‡§∞‡•á‡§™‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§¨‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø-‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§¢‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The decisions regarding the policy repo rate are taken by the six-member Monetary Policy Committee (MPC), headed by the RBI Governor.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§™‡•â‡§≤‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§∞‡•á‡§™‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§¨‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à ‡§ó‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§õ‡§π ‡§∏‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø (‡§è‡§Æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Ä) ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§

question: Q.29: A mixed economy involves both private and public ownership. What was a distinctive feature of India's mixed economy model?
options: Public sector dominance in core industries
correct: Public sector dominance in core industries

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Public sector dominance in core industries.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- While a mixed economy theoretically involves a balance between public and private sectors, the Indian model, particularly from 1950s to 1991, was distinctive for its strong emphasis on the public sector. The state took on the primary role in capital-intensive and strategic sectors (the 'commanding heights'), while the private sector was allowed to operate, but was heavily regulated and controlled.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§ú‡§¨‡§ï‡§ø ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ö ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§® ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•â‡§°‡§≤, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á 1950 ‡§∏‡•á 1991 ‡§§‡§ï, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§¨‡•Ç‡§§ ‡§ú‡•ã‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä-‡§ó‡§π‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§£‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ('‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§π‡§æ‡§á‡§ü‡•ç‡§∏') ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§à, ‡§ú‡§¨‡§ï‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§à, ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§® ‡§á‡§∏‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The focus was on production and self-reliance, not consumerism.
- The model was the opposite of full privatisation.
- The economy was characterized by the presence of a strong licensing system (License Raj), not its absence.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

question: Q.30: As per Deloitte, how much will AI in healthcare boost India's GDP by 2025?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- This question refers to a specific projection made in a report by the consulting firm Deloitte. Their analysis on the economic impact of Artificial Intelligence (AI) suggested that the application of AI in India's healthcare sector could contribute an additional USD 25-30 billion to the country's GDP by 2025. This boost would come from improved efficiency, better diagnostics, personalized medicine, and streamlined hospital operations.

question: Q.370) As per the National Sample Survey, what was identified as a pronounced deprivation in well-being in India?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The National Sample Survey's (NSS) consumption expenditure surveys are crucial for estimating the levels of **poverty**. Over the decades, these surveys have consistently identified poverty, measured through consumption-based metrics, as a major and pronounced form of deprivation affecting a significant portion of the Indian population.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **Economic growth** and **high literacy rates** are positive indicators, not deprivations.
- While **unemployment** is a significant deprivation, poverty is a more encompassing measure of material deprivation that the NSS has historically focused on.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The NSO's (formerly NSSO) large-scale surveys on consumption expenditure have been the bedrock of official poverty estimation in India for many years.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The methodology for calculating the 'poverty line' in India has been a subject of intense debate among economists for decades.

question: Q.31: Tariff reforms were central to the liberalisation of trade. What happened to import tariffs after 1991?
options: It was replaced with import bans

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- A key component of the 1991 trade liberalisation policy was to reduce the high levels of protection given to domestic industries. This was achieved by systematically and gradually reducing import tariffs (customs duties) across a wide range of goods. The peak customs duty, which was over 150% in 1991, has been progressively brought down over the years to integrate the Indian economy with the global economy.

question: Q.32: Which initiative is intended to encourage domestic manufacturing and attract foreign investment?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The 'Make in India' initiative was launched by the Government of India in 2014 with the primary objective of transforming India into a global design and manufacturing hub. It aims to encourage both multinational and domestic companies to manufacture their products in India by improving the ease of doing business and attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) into the manufacturing sector.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- '‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï ‡§á‡§® ‡§á‡§Ç‡§°‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ' ‡§™‡§π‡§≤ 2014 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§°‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§á‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§¶‡§≤‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§à ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ò‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡•Ç ‡§¶‡•ã‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•á ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ (‡§è‡§´‡§°‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à) ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.33: Privatisation under the 1991 reforms primarily involved:
options: selling government shares in public sector enterprises
correct: selling government shares in public sector enterprises

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Selling government shares in public sector enterprises.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ø‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•á‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The policy of privatisation, which was a core part of the 1991 reforms, was primarily implemented through 'disinvestment'. Disinvestment is the process where the government sells its shares (equity) in Public Sector Enterprises (PSEs) to private investors or the public. The aim was to introduce private ownership and management to improve efficiency and raise resources for the government.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø, ‡§ú‡•ã 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á '‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂' ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§à ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§µ‡§π ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à ‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç (PSEs) ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•á ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ø‡§∞ (‡§á‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡•Ä) ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§®‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡•á‡§ö‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§® ‡§ú‡•Å‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Increasing subsidies and nationalising companies are actions associated with a state-controlled economy, the opposite of the 1991 reforms.
- Reducing bank interest rates is a monetary policy action, separate from the structural reform of privatisation.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§∏‡§¨‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§°‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø-‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ú‡•Å‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡•ã 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
- ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§¨‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§à ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ó ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- Privatisation and disinvestment have been pursued by successive governments in India since 1991, leading to a significant change in the ownership structure of the Indian industry.

- ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•ã 1991 ‡§∏‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§∏‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§¨‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.34: Which of the following is an example of structural unemployment?
options: A worker losing their job due to a recession
A worker choosing not to work due to a lack of job opportunities
A worker being unable to find a job due to discrimination
A worker being unable to find a job due to a lack of skills in a new and expanding industry
correct: A worker being unable to find a job due to a lack of skills in a new and expanding industry

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: A worker being unable to find a job due to a lack of skills in a new and expanding industry.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§è‡§ï ‡§®‡§è ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•å‡§∂‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§®‡•å‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Structural unemployment occurs when there is a long-term mismatch between the skills that workers possess and the skills that employers demand. This often happens due to technological changes, shifts in the economy (e.g., from manufacturing to services), or globalisation. A worker lacking the skills for a new industry (e.g., a typist in the age of computers) is a classic example of structural unemployment.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§§‡§¨ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à ‡§ú‡§¨ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡•å‡§ú‡•Ç‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•å‡§∂‡§≤ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡•å‡§∂‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ö ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§® ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§§‡§ï‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç, ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ (‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ï), ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§®‡§è ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ï‡•å‡§∂‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï (‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è, ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ü‡§æ‡§á‡§™‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü) ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Losing a job due to a recession is an example of cyclical unemployment.
- Choosing not to work is voluntary unemployment.
- Inability to find a job due to discrimination is a social issue, not a type of unemployment in the economic sense.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§®‡•å‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö‡•Å‡§®‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§®‡•å‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- Structural unemployment is considered more persistent and harder to solve than cyclical unemployment, often requiring policies like retraining and education programs.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§π‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§†‡§ø‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®: ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The decline of coal mining jobs in many developed countries due to the shift towards renewable energy is a major contemporary example of structural unemployment.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§®‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ì‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§à ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ñ‡§®‡§® ‡§®‡•å‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ü ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§® ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.35: Special Economic Zones (SEZs) were established to promote export-oriented industrialisation. What is a primary incentive offered to firms operating in SEZs?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Tax holidays and infrastructure support.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- SEZs are specially demarcated geographical areas within a country that have more liberal economic laws than the rest of the country. To attract investment and promote exports, firms operating within SEZs are offered a package of incentives. The primary incentives include tax holidays (exemption from corporate income tax for a certain period), exemption from customs duties on imported inputs, and access to high-quality infrastructure.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

question: Q.37: Tourism is classified as a tertiary activity because it involves:

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Providing services to people.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§è‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Economic activities are classified into three sectors: Primary (extraction of raw materials, e.g., agriculture), Secondary (manufacturing and processing, e.g., industry), and Tertiary (services). Tourism does not involve producing a tangible good. Instead, it involves providing a range of services like transportation, accommodation, food, and entertainment to tourists. Therefore, it is a quintessential tertiary sector activity.

question: Q.38: India has been a World Trade Organization (WTO) member since ___.

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The World Trade Organization (WTO) was officially established on January 1, 1995, under the Marrakesh Agreement. India was not only a founding member of the WTO from its inception in 1995 but was also a founding member of its predecessor, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), in 1948.

question: Q.39: When was the Monetary Policy Framework Agreement (MPFA) signed between the Government of India and the Reserve Bank?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Monetary Policy Framework Agreement (MPFA) was signed between the Government of India and the RBI on February 20, 2015. This agreement formally adopted a flexible inflation targeting (FIT) framework for India's monetary policy. Under this agreement, the RBI's primary objective became price stability while keeping in mind the objective of growth.

question: Q.40: Which institution played a key role in influencing the structural reforms of the industrial sector in India post 1991?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: IMF and World Bank.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§Ü‡§à‡§è‡§Æ‡§è‡§´ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- In 1991, India faced a severe balance of payments crisis. To overcome this, India sought a bailout loan from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank. These institutions provided the necessary financial assistance but attached certain conditionalities, which included implementing a Structural Adjustment Program. This program required India to undertake major economic reforms, including liberalising its industrial and trade policies, reducing the role of the public sector, and opening up the economy to foreign investment.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 1991 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡§°‡§º‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¨‡•Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§®‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑ (‡§Ü‡§à‡§è‡§Æ‡§è‡§´) ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§∏‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡•á‡§≤‡§Ü‡§â‡§ü ‡§ã‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§®‡•á ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§® ‡§ï‡•Å‡§õ ‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•Ä ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•á, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§≤‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§

- **‡§Ü‡§∞‡§¨‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à** ‡§Æ‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§® ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§à‡§è‡§Æ‡§è‡§´ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡•á‡•§
- **‡§®‡§æ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§°** ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§ã‡§£ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

- 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ö‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∞, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≠‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§≤‡§ó‡§≠‡§ó ‡§§‡•Ä‡§® ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§π ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§π ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§

question: Q.371) By how much did India's merchandise exports grow from 1990-91 to 2000-01, as a result of the trade and foreign investment reforms introduced in the 1991 policy?

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: B) From $18.4 billion to $44.8 billion
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The 1991 reforms dismantled the 'License Raj', devalued the rupee, and rationalized tariffs. As a direct result, India's merchandise exports saw substantial growth, more than doubling from approximately **$18.4 billion** in 1990-91 to about **$44.8 billion** in 2000-01.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The other figures are incorrect data points for the export growth in that specific decade.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The opening up of trade was a cornerstone of the 1991 reforms, shifting India from an inward-looking model to a more export-oriented economy.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- Before 1991, importing even basic items like computers required a government license, a process that could often take months.

options: It is the most profitable sector.

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- An intermediate good is something that is used as an input in the production of other goods or services. Infrastructure (like power, transport, communication) is considered a 'universal' intermediate because it is a fundamental input required for the functioning and production activities of almost every other sector of the economy, from agriculture to manufacturing to services.

explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Infrastructure is not always the most profitable sector, as it often involves large, long-term investments.
- It is not universally available; lack of adequate infrastructure is a major problem in many developing countries.
- While it does connect urban and rural areas, its role as a universal input is a more fundamental economic reason for the term.

question: Q.42: Who is considered unemployed under the Usual Status (US) measure?
options: Someone working only one day a week
Someone not working but seeking work over a long period

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Someone not working but seeking work over a long period.

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- In India, unemployment is measured using different approaches by the National Sample Survey Office (NSSO). The Usual Status (US) approach uses a reference period of 365 days preceding the date of the survey. A person is considered unemployed on the usual status basis if they were not working but were seeking or available for work for a relatively long period during the reference year. It captures chronic unemployment.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø (NSSO) ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§£‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø (US) ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§£ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ñ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡•á 365 ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§µ‡§π ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§π‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§® ‡§Ö‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§∂ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§â‡§™‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡§ï‡§°‡§º‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.43: Which of the following is an example of a tertiary activity?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The tertiary sector of the economy is the service sector. It involves the provision of services rather than the production of tangible goods. Teaching is a service provided to students. Other examples include banking, healthcare, transportation, and retail.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§® ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§® ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§õ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§

- In most developed and developing economies, including India, the tertiary sector is the largest contributor to the Gross Domestic Product (GDP).

- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤ ‡§ò‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡•Ç ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶ (‡§ú‡•Ä‡§°‡•Ä‡§™‡•Ä) ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¨‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- Some economists further classify the service sector into Quaternary (knowledge-based activities like research and IT) and Quinary (high-level decision-making) sectors.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§ï‡•Å‡§õ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§ó‡•á ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï (‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®-‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Å ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§à‡§ü‡•Ä) ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡§ï (‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö-‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø ‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á) ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§

question: Q.44: Which of the following is considered a major social development outcome of India's economic reforms since 1991?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Improvement in life expectancy.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The high economic growth triggered by the 1991 reforms led to a significant reduction in poverty and an increase in government revenue, which allowed for greater spending on social sectors like health and education. This resulted in notable improvements in social development indicators. Life expectancy at birth in India has seen a steady and significant improvement, rising from around 58 years in 1991 to nearly 70 years in recent times.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§π‡•Å‡§è ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§®‡•á ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§π‡•Å‡§è‡•§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡•ã 1991 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ó‡§≠‡§ó 58 ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ó‡§≠‡§ó 70 ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Widening of the fiscal deficit is a negative economic outcome, not a positive social one. Fiscal consolidation was a goal of the reforms.
- The poverty rate has significantly decreased, not increased, since 1991.
- The literacy rate has significantly increased, not decreased.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ò‡§æ‡§ü‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§®‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§® ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
- 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§´‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§à ‡§π‡•à, ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡•Ä ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§´‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§π‡•Å‡§à ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- While economic reforms are often debated for their impact on inequality, their positive contribution to overall poverty reduction and improvement in health and education indicators is widely acknowledged.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§â‡§®‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§¨‡§π‡§∏ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à, ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§®‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- According to World Bank data, the percentage of the Indian population living in extreme poverty (on less than $2.15 a day) fell from over 45% in 1993 to around 10% before the pandemic.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§ï‡§°‡§º‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞, ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§π‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§§ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡§ø‡§® $2.15 ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∞) 1993 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç 45% ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á ‡§≤‡§ó‡§≠‡§ó 10% ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§

question: Q.45: Post-independence, India adopted a planned approach to build a mixed economy. Which sector was given top priority under the First Five-Year Plan?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The First Five-Year Plan (1951-1956) was launched at a time when India was facing a severe food crisis, high inflation, and the influx of refugees after partition. Therefore, the plan's primary aim was to overcome the food crisis and control inflation. It gave the highest priority to the agricultural sector, including investments in irrigation and power projects like the Bhakra-Nangal Dam.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ (1951-1956) ‡§ê‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§à ‡§•‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§¨ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü, ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§® ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§Æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§π‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§è, ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ñ‡§°‡§º‡§æ-‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§à ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§ø‡§ú‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Industry, particularly heavy industry, was the focus of the Second Five-Year Plan.
- Defence and the Tertiary sector were not the primary focus of the first plan.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó, ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
- ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§•‡•á‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The First Five-Year Plan was largely successful in achieving its targets, with the economy growing faster than anticipated and food production increasing significantly.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•á ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§´‡•Ä ‡§π‡§¶ ‡§§‡§ï ‡§∏‡§´‡§≤ ‡§∞‡§π‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§® ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§π‡•Å‡§à‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The First Five-Year Plan was based on the Harrod-Domar model, which emphasized the role of savings and investment in driving economic growth.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡§∞‡•ã‡§°-‡§°‡•ã‡§Æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•â‡§°‡§≤ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§ö‡§§ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•ã‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§

classification.subject: Economics
classification.subTopic: Types of Banks & Banking Sector Reforms

question: Q.46: Which of the following was among the first financial institutions in India to receive an 'in principle' approval from the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) to set up a bank in the private sector?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- After the banking sector reforms in the early 1990s, the RBI issued guidelines for the establishment of new private sector banks. In 1994, HDFC Limited (a housing finance company) was among the first batch of institutions to receive an 'in-principle' approval from the RBI to set up a commercial bank, which became HDFC Bank. This marked the return of private players to the Indian banking scene after decades of nationalization.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

question: Q.47: Which type of unemployment is most prevalent in Indian agriculture during the non-sowing season?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Seasonal unemployment occurs when people are unemployed at certain times of the year because they work in industries where demand for labor is seasonal. Indian agriculture is heavily dependent on the monsoon and has distinct sowing and harvesting seasons. During the lean period between these seasons (the non-sowing season), there is less work on farms, leading to widespread seasonal unemployment among agricultural laborers.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

question: Q.48: What is one key indicator of economic development that showed consistent improvement in India post 1991?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The 1991 crisis was triggered by a severe shortage of foreign exchange reserves. A major success of the post-reform period has been the consistent and massive build-up of these reserves. Due to increased exports, robust software service earnings, and strong capital inflows (FDI and FPI), India's forex reserves grew from just over $1 billion in 1991 to over $600 billion in recent years. This provides a strong cushion against external shocks.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 1991 ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≠‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§´‡§≤‡§§‡§æ ‡§á‡§® ‡§≠‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•á ‡§™‡•à‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ ‡§∞‡§π‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡•á ‡§π‡•Å‡§è ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§, ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§¨‡•Ç‡§§ ‡§∏‡•â‡§´‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•á‡§Ø‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§¨‡•Ç‡§§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§π (‡§è‡§´‡§°‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§è‡§´‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≠‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§∞ 1991 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§´ 1 ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡§® ‡§°‡•â‡§≤‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç 600 ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡§® ‡§°‡•â‡§≤‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ù‡§ü‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§´ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§¨‡•Ç‡§§ ‡§§‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- **Fiscal deficit** has remained a persistent challenge, although efforts have been made to control it.
- **Black money** continues to be a major issue in the Indian economy.

- **‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ò‡§æ‡§ü‡§æ** ‡§è‡§ï ‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ö‡•Å‡§®‡•å‡§§‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü ‡§π‡•à, ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§á‡§∏‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§è ‡§ó‡§è ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
- **‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ß‡§®** ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- **‡§∂‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§¶‡§∞** ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ï ‡§π‡•à, ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§¨ ‡§§‡§ï ‡§á‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§´‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü ‡§π‡•à, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≠‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡•á 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ß‡•á ‡§ú‡•Å‡§°‡§º‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.conclusion:

- High foreign exchange reserves are a symbol of India's improved macroeconomic stability and its stronger position in the global economy since the 1991 reforms.

question: Q.49: Which sector witnessed the slowest growth during the period of 1947 to 1991?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- During the pre-reform period (1947-1991), India's development strategy was heavily focused on industrialization. While the Green Revolution in the mid-1960s boosted food grain production, the overall growth rate of the agricultural sector remained low and volatile. Issues like inadequate public investment (outside the Green Revolution belts), flawed land reforms, and dependence on monsoons led to its sluggish performance compared to the industrial and service sectors.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞-‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø (1947-1991) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§®, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∞‡§£‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§ú‡§¨‡§ï‡§ø 1960 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•á ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§® ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§®‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§π‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ (‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§ü ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡§∞), ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§ü‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§® ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The industrial and service sectors, though growing from a small base and facing their own issues, generally grew faster than the agricultural sector during this period.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§è‡§ï ‡§õ‡•ã‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º ‡§∞‡§π‡•á ‡§•‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§π‡•á ‡§•‡•á, ‡§Ü‡§Æ ‡§§‡•å‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡•á‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The relatively slow growth in agriculture, which employed the majority of the population, was a key reason for the persistence of poverty in India during this period.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂ ‡§Ü‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§§ ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§® ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§®‡•á ‡§∞‡§π‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The average annual growth rate of the Indian economy during the first three decades after independence was around 3.5%, which was derisively termed the 'Hindu rate of growth' by some economists.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á ‡§§‡•Ä‡§® ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§® ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∏‡§§ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§≤‡§ó‡§≠‡§ó 3.5% ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§õ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï '‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§¶‡§∞' ‡§ï‡§π‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§

question: Q.50: Which sector dominated India's national income before independence?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Indian economy under British rule was overwhelmingly agrarian. The agricultural sector was the primary source of livelihood for the vast majority of the population (over 75%) and was also the largest contributor to the country's national income. However, it was characterized by low productivity and stagnation due to exploitative colonial policies.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ü‡§ø‡§∂ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•Ä‡§® ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§® ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§ (75% ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§ ‡§•‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¨‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø, ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∂‡•ã‡§∑‡§ï ‡§î‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§†‡§π‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Industry, banking, trade, and transport were all underdeveloped. The British did not promote a modern industrial or service sector base in India, except where it served their own colonial interests (e.g., railways for transporting raw materials).

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó, ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡§® ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ú‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§®‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§∏‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§â‡§®‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã (‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á, ‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡§® ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡§µ‡•á)‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The dominance of a stagnant agricultural sector was the defining feature of India's economic backwardness at the time of independence.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡§ø‡§õ‡§°‡§º‡•á‡§™‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The first modern industries in India, such as cotton textiles in the 1850s and the iron and steel industry in the early 1900s, were largely established through Indian capital and enterprise, despite a lack of support from the colonial government.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó, ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø 1850 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§î‡§∞ 1900 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ü‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•å‡§π ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§á‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§§ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó, ‡§î‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•Ç‡§¶, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§´‡•Ä ‡§π‡§¶ ‡§§‡§ï ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§è ‡§ó‡§è ‡§•‡•á‡•§

question: Q.372) During which Five Year Plan did India shift its focus towards the liberalisation and globalisation of its economy, marking a significant policy change?

explanation.summary: Correct Answer: B) Eighth Five Year Plan
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The major economic reforms of Liberalisation, Privatisation, and Globalisation (LPG) were introduced in 1991. The **Eighth Five-Year Plan (1992-1997)** was the first plan to be formulated in this new, liberalized economic environment. It incorporated the goals of the new policies, aiming for higher growth rates and private sector participation.
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The Sixth and Seventh plans were pre-reform era plans. The Tenth plan came much later.
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- Due to the political instability and crisis of 1990-91, there was a 'plan holiday' of two annual plans before the Eighth Plan formally initiated the era of indicative planning in a liberalized framework.
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The Eighth Plan is considered highly successful, as it achieved an average annual growth rate of 6.8%, exceeding its target of 5.6%.

question: Q.51) Which of the following correctly describes India's foreign trade structure at the time of independence?
options: Export of raw materials and import of manufactured goods
correct: Export of raw materials and import of manufactured goods

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Export of raw materials and import of manufactured goods.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The foreign trade pattern during British rule was a classic colonial structure. India was systematically transformed into a supplier of cheap raw materials (like raw cotton, jute, indigo) for British industries and a captive market for their expensive, machine-made finished goods (like cotton textiles). This structure destroyed India's traditional handicraft industries and drained its wealth.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

explanation.analysis_incorrect:

question: Q.52) Employment patterns during 1947-1991 showed limited diversification. Which sector employed the largest share of India's workforce throughout this period?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Despite the emphasis on industrialization in the Five-Year Plans, there was no significant structural shift in employment from agriculture to industry. Throughout the 1947-1991 period, the agricultural sector continued to employ the largest proportion of the workforce, typically around 65-70%. While industry's share in GDP grew, its capacity to absorb labor remained limited.

question: Q.53) Which of the following indicators is NOT included in the Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI)?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Monthly Per Capita Expenditure.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) is designed to capture non-monetary deprivations. It is based on three dimensions: Health, Education, and Standard of Living. These are measured by indicators like Nutrition, Child Mortality, Years of Schooling, School Attendance, Cooking Fuel, Sanitation, Drinking Water, Electricity, Housing, and Assets. Monthly Per Capita Expenditure is a measure of consumption or income, used for defining monetary poverty, and is explicitly excluded from the MPI framework.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï (MPI) ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ó‡•à‡§∞-‡§Æ‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡§ï‡§°‡§º‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§°‡§ø‡§ú‡§º‡§æ‡§á‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§§‡•Ä‡§® ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•à: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•§ ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡§£, ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§¶‡§∞, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø, ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§à‡§Ç‡§ß‡§®, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ, ‡§™‡•Ä‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä, ‡§¨‡§ø‡§ú‡§≤‡•Ä, ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø ‡§â‡§™‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§Æ‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§á‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á MPI ‡§¢‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

- **Nutrition** is an indicator under the Health dimension.
- **Years of Schooling** is an indicator under the Education dimension.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- **‡§¨‡§ø‡§ú‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§§‡§ï ‡§™‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ö** ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡§π‡§§ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ï ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The key idea behind MPI is that poverty is not just about a lack of money, but a complex problem involving multiple overlapping deprivations.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- MPI ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•Ä‡§õ‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§π‡•à ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤ ‡§™‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§ï‡§à ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ú‡•Å‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ú‡§ü‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.54) The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) was established to formalise inflation targeting. How many members constitute India's MPC?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) of India is a six-member committee constituted by the Central Government following the amendment to the RBI Act, 1934. The composition is as follows:
  - Three internal members from the RBI: the Governor (Chairperson), the Deputy Governor in charge of monetary policy, and one officer of the RBI nominated by the Central Board.
  - Three external members appointed by the central government who are experts in the field of economics or banking.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø (MPC) ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§¨‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ, 1934 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ã‡§ß‡§® ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ó‡§†‡§ø‡§§ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§õ‡§π ‡§∏‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§π‡•à:
  - ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§¨‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à ‡§∏‡•á ‡§§‡•Ä‡§® ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø: ‡§ó‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§∞ (‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑), ‡§Æ‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§°‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§∞, ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§¨‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§° ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§¨‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡•§
  - ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§§‡•Ä‡§® ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§ú‡•ç‡§û ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§

- ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§è‡§Å ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§¨‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ñ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à ‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§£‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§® ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ï‡•á‡•§

- The MPC is responsible for fixing the benchmark policy interest rate (repo rate) to keep inflation within the target range. This has brought greater transparency and accountability to India's monetary policy.

question: Q.55) Human development also involves freedom, security and dignity in life. The first Human Development Report was published in which year?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The first Human Development Report, which introduced the Human Development Index (HDI) as an alternative to purely income-based measures of development, was published by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in 1990. The report was led by Pakistani economist Mahbub ul Haq.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï (HDI) ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Ø-‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, 1990 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ (UNDP) ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§à ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¨‡•Ç‡§¨ ‡§â‡§≤ ‡§π‡§ï ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§ 1990 ‡§µ‡§π ‡§ê‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§π‡•à ‡§ú‡§¨ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§î‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§™‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.conclusion:

- The Human Development Report shifted the global discourse on development from a narrow focus on economic growth (GDP) to a broader focus on human well-being and capabilities.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ (‡§ú‡•Ä‡§°‡•Ä‡§™‡•Ä) ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§® ‡§∏‡•á ‡§π‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§

question: Q.56) Which institution played a major role in supporting India's liberalisation policy during the 1991 crisis?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Faced with a severe balance of payments crisis in 1991, India had to seek emergency financial assistance from the IMF. The IMF provided a bailout loan, but this support was conditional upon India implementing a comprehensive set of economic reforms. These reforms, known as the Structural Adjustment Program, involved liberalising the economy, opening it to foreign trade and investment, and reducing the role of the state.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 1991 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•Å‡§è, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§à‡§è‡§Æ‡§è‡§´ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ü‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•Ä ‡§™‡§°‡§º‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§à‡§è‡§Æ‡§è‡§´ ‡§®‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡•á‡§≤‡§Ü‡§â‡§ü ‡§ã‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§® ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§® ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§∏‡•á‡§ü ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§§ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§® ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ, ‡§á‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§≤‡§®‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The **RBI** was the domestic implementer of monetary reforms but not the external supporter.
- The **Election Commission** is a constitutional body for conducting elections.
- **NITI Aayog** was established much later, in 2015.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- **‡§Ü‡§∞‡§¨‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à** ‡§Æ‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ò‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡•Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§® ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç‡•§
- **‡§ö‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§µ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó** ‡§ö‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡•à‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§π‡•à‡•§
- **‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó** ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡§æ ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, 2015 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§π‡•Å‡§à ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The 1991 crisis and the role of the IMF were pivotal in forcing a major shift in India's long-standing economic policies.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- The set of policies promoted by the IMF and World Bank during this period is often referred to as the 'Washington Consensus'.

- ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§® ‡§Ü‡§à‡§è‡§Æ‡§è‡§´ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•á‡§ü ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ '‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó‡§ü‡§® ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø' ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.57) What was one of the major characteristics of India's economy at the time of independence in 1947?
options: Heavy dependence on agriculture and low productivity
correct: Heavy dependence on agriculture and low productivity

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Heavy dependence on agriculture and low productivity.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡§§‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- In 1947, the Indian economy was a classic example of an underdeveloped, stagnant colonial economy. Its defining characteristic was the overwhelming dependence of the population (about 75%) on agriculture. This agriculture, however, was marked by feudal land relations, primitive technology, and very low productivity, leading to widespread poverty.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 1947 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞ ‡§î‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ (‡§≤‡§ó‡§≠‡§ó 75%) ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø, ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§Ç, ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ö‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§π‡•Å‡§à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The services and manufacturing sectors were extremely underdeveloped.
- India did not have a strong trade surplus; its trade was structured to benefit Britain.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡•á‡•§
- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§¨‡•Ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§•‡§æ; ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ü‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠ ‡§™‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- This heavy dependence on a low-productivity primary sector was the central economic challenge facing the newly independent India.
